title: community-resilience-can-turn-help-elphinstone-gifford-haddington-longniddry-tranent
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at five of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Elphinstone. Picture: Google MapsElphinstoneDOG walking, collecting prescriptions, shopping and much more are on offer from generous volunteers in Elphinstone.A spokeswoman for the community highlighted a number of services were on offer to people during the coronavirus pandemic.She said: ldquoThis care has included help with dog walking, collecting prescriptions, shopping, daily delivery of meals and food, a friendly chat over the phone or at a distance from the garden gate.ldquoA number of community partners have rallied to ensure that everyone is cared for during this Covid- pandemic.ldquoThis has only been possible with the operational support of East Lothian Roots and Fruits, Elphinstone Community Association, Elphinstone Primary School, East Lothian Council, Councillor Colin McGinn, Pennypit Community Trust, East Lothian Foodbank, Home-Start East Lothian, Walk With Scott Foundation, Heavy Sound, Social Bite, Tesco, Fair Share, Hibernian Community Foundation and generous donations from McInroy  Wood [Haddington].ldquoThis important work has greatly strengthened relationships and working practices that will continue to grow and develop long after we overcome this devastating pandemic.ldquoCollectively, this network has shown incredible reach, capacity, experience and skills as they endeavour to meet the needs of everyone in need of support.Contact detailsAny residents of Elphinstone who would like to request support can contact the team through email ndash colinmcginn@hotmail ndash or  .Gford. Picture: Google MapsGfordHEARING aid batteries have become the latest item keeping volunteers in Gfordrsquos community resilience team busy with calls for help renewing them.The resilience team has access to replacement batteries through the East Lothian Council community hubs soanyone in need should get in touch.Meanwhile, the team have also spoken about the ldquoprivilege they feel getting to know the stories of so many of their local residents.The grouprsquos spokesperson said: ldquoWe have been getting to know so many of our residents through talking with them and hearing about their lives we have one man who cooked for royalty and so many others with extraordinary tales to share.ldquoIt is a real privilege to get to know them.Contact detailsAnyone needing help can contact: Jo Allen, GCC chair, on   or ChairGfordCC@gmail Adam White, GCC vice chair, on   or adamjswhite@outlook Wendy Ferguson, GCC treasurer, on   or wendyferguson.wf@gmail Aniko Schuetz Bradwell, minister, on   or aschuetzbradwell@churchofscotland.org.ukHaddingtonHaddingtonAN INCREASING number of people are getting in touch with community resilience volunteers in Haddington.The townrsquos community council has been at the heart of setting up a squad of volunteers to help people during the coronavirus pandemic.Chris McEwan, vice-chairman of the community council, stressed they would do whatever they could to help those who needed assistance.He said: ldquoWe have managed in the past few weeks to get our contact details out there a lot better.ldquoPeople are phoning and contacting us, and our volunteers are basically now really getting themselves into a nice routine.ldquoThey have got quite a few people that they are looking after week on week.Services being offered through the resilience volunteers are also increasing.Collections of shopping and prescriptions have been available for a number of weeks.Now, a dog walking service and getting tradesmen out to solve issues in the home have also been introduced.Mr McEwan took the time to once again praise the efforts of the volunteers.He said: ldquoI must say, the town has really, really done well and I have to thank all my volunteers and the people I donrsquot know about who are helping as well.ldquoWe have had people who have had maintenance issues and we have managed to get some tradesmen out to them.ldquoTradesmen are offering to help, some doing it for revenue but a couple doing it for nothing people are helping for nothing.Mr McEwan also highlighted that there was a wide range of information on the grouprsquos website, with sections set up to alert people to community help and coronavirus.On top of that, there is a section for food deliveries, ranging from butchers and bakers to prepared meals and takeaways which are open in the town.The community council plans to keep the list as up to date as possible for people.Contact detailsAnyone looking to find out more can visit www.haddingtoncc.org.uk while anyone looking for assistance can e-mail resilienthcc@haddingtoncc.org.uk or call  .Longniddry. Picture: Google MapsLongniddryONE resident in Longniddry has started offering a free dog walking service for those unable to take their four-legged friend on its daily stroll.Those interested should contact Danni Anderson on Facebook.Meanwhile, the villagersquos resilience effort is still helping those in need and answering queries from residents.It is being led by the local church and supported by Longniddry Community Council.Sheila Jamieson told the Courier that people in the village have been helping family and neighbours on their own accord, so enquiries to her are still fairly low.However, she has still received some enquiries, such as people asking how they can get hearing aid batteries, food parcels and online food deliveries.She currently has  volunteers ready to help her deliver the resilience effort should the need arise.Sheila said: ldquoAs long as people are getting the help they need ndash we are still here and doing what we can.ldquoIrsquom overwhelmed and so grateful for the volunteers and the nice community.ldquoAll of the people in the community are coming together. We are coping at the moment and getting calls from the council with other people who might also need help.As with other resilience groups, it is helping with delivering prescriptions ndash but the local pharmacy offers a delivery service to those over the age of .Contact detailsThose who need any help or assistance can call Sheila Jamieson on  .Tranent. Picture: Google MapsTranentVOLUNTEERS covering Tranent and Elphinstone delivered leaflets to every house in the area, with help from Ross High Rugby Club, reminding people of the help they can receive from their local resilience group.The number of people signed up to volunteer in the area has now risen to , as the number of calls the group receives also continues to rise.The resilience effort in Tranent and Elphinstone is being led by the local community council and overseen by member Mike Falconer.People are continuing to help out with requests such as collecting shopping, picking up prescriptions, and walking dogs.The resilience group is also helping Fundamental Foods and the Pennypit Trust with food deliveries, as well as assisting with its school hub effort.Contact detailsUpdates are also posted on the resilience Facebook page, lsquoTranent Emergency Response ndash Coronavirusrsquo.Updates, information and advice are also shared on Radio Saltire as part of its community information feature.Anyone needing assistance can call   or email tranentemergencyresponse@gmailIF YOUR resilience group would like to purchase copies of the Courier to deliver to residents who are shielding and unable to leave their homes then please email Courier Editor Robbie Scott via rscott@eastlothiancourier for details. Copies can be delivered to a destination of your choice before being distributed by your volunteers.

title: community-resilience-can-turn-help-dirleton-dunbar-east-linton-east-lammermuir-gullane-north-berwick
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at six of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Dirleton Castle.G Laird and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons Licence.DirletonTHE resilience effort in Dirleton continues to help local residents and has launched a community larder filled with essential items.The Dirleton Area Resilience Teamis led by lead co-ordinator David Tait.Volunteers have continued to deliver food and medicines to the most vulnerable in their community, as well as those shielding and selfisolating.Further planning has made shopping and prescription collection easier for residents and safer for volunteers.Dedicated shopping days, and deadlines for food and medicine orders to be submitted, are in place.This reduces the volunteersrsquo exposure to potential harm at shops and chemists.DART has also launched the Dirleton essentials community larder via Facebook.The larder is stocked with essential items such as pasta, tea, coffee, toiletries, newspapers, hearing aid batteries and fresh fruit and vegetables.The group also continues to receive donations of fresh eggs from Ferrygate Farm and other produce from Aldi and Tesco.Other special items such as soups and crumbles are also donated.To ensure that all safety protocols are met, strict social distancing rules are in place.The larder is open MondayFriday and can be accessed by calling the dedicated booking line on   between am and noon for a -minute appointment between pm and pm.For those who are isolating, there is a dedicated booking line for deliveries in operation Tuesday-Thursday am-noon.This can be contacted on  .David said: ldquoThe larder has been proving a vital asset to the community and is used on a regular basis. All items are free and it does not cost anything to use.ldquoThrough successful grant applications for funding, DART has the unique ability to further support the village with continued stocking of the larder and will have a hardship fund so we can better support our community.ldquoAs an organisation we are continually assessing and forward planning for every eventuality in this crisis, and will continue to deliver on its primary purpose.ldquoThe community has massive spirit and itrsquos a marvellous place to live special thanks go out to all of the team at DART, all volunteers and, of course, everyone in the village, Archerfield and surrounding areas. More exciting things are in the pipeline and we will be sharing the news soon.Contact detailsIf you are in need of assistance, contact DART.coordinators@outlook or call .DunbarDunbarCOMMUNITY resilience volunteers in Dunbar have received a pound, cash boost.The townrsquos community council received funding from the National Lottery Community Fund on Monday.The community council is at the heart of the resilience efforts in the town, and neighbouring West Barns, during the coronavirus outbreak.The group use their large network of volunteers to provide essential free food and other supplies to vulnerable people, including the elderly, during the Covid- pandemic.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of Dunbarrsquos community council, was delighted with the funding boost.She said: ldquoWe have allocated the pound, to our hardship fund and we have a small  who will review referrals.ldquoWhat we are expecting is, as time progresses, people find themselves in need of some financial support that would make a dference, whether that is for school shoes or whatever.ldquoWe are calling them lsquomicro-grantsrsquo at the moment.ldquoThe sum pound, sounds a lot but in fact it will disappear very, very quicklywe do not manage it well.Referrals can be made by a iety of groups throughout the area, including churches, Rotary groups and debt services.It is hoped the referrals can then be reviewed within  hours and grants given to those in need.Mrs Swan added: ldquoIt will be interesting to see what happens.ldquoOddly, it has been quite quiet but I donrsquot think anybody knows what the repercussions are going to be in  weeks or three monthsrsquo time.The volunteers continue to provide lsquogood neighbourrsquo services on request, such as shopping, prescription collection and pet care.Dunbar and West Barns is split into nine clusters: Shore and Harbour Group High Street, Parsonspool to Kings Court West End to Countess Road Belhaven and Kirk Park West Barns and the Beveridge Row development Queenrsquos Road and the new housing developments Hallhill, Kellie Road and to the railway line Brodie Road east and north to the railway line and Brodie Road west and north to the railway line.A Single Point of Contacthas been assigned to each of the clusters to help direct volunteers where needed.George Robertson, chairman of Dunbar and East Linton Area Partnershipand a member of Dunbar Community Council, said: ldquoWe are also finding an increase in the requests for support for the lsquoshieldedrsquo category being passed on from East Lothian Council.Contact detailsFor more information, go to Dunbar and District Coronavirus Community Helperswww.facebook groups  or Dunbar Community Council onwww.facebook DunbarCommunityCouncilEast Linton. Picture: Google MapsEast LintonVOLUNTEERS continue to be on standby throughout the area covered by Dunpender Community Council.The group, which includes East Linton, Whitekirk and Whittingehame, has set up a team of willing volunteers in response to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.Dunpender Community Resilience Team is standing by and Judith Priest, chairwoman of the community council, said the situation remained much the same as previously.The East Linton website includes information on shopping, government, NHS and East Lothian Council advice, as well as numbers of all the community councillors.Contail detailsInformation is provided on the Tyninghame Village Hall website ndash tyninghamevillagehall.org.uk ndash while there are also details on eastlinton.uk.Every household in the area has also received a flyer, which features two numbers ndash   and   ndash which people can callthey need help with shopping, collecting medicines or prescriptions, or just want to talk to someone.Stenton.kim traynor and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons Licence.East LammermuirA FUND supporting residents of rural villages in the east of the county has been set up.East Lammermuir Community Council, which covers villages including Spott, Stenton, Innerwick and Oldhamstocks, has launched the new Covid- Community Support Fund.Leaflets have been delivered to homes in the area highlighting the scheme, which aims to support residents who have been affected by Covid-.Chris Bruce, chairman of the community council, said finance had been secured through Fred.Olsen, the company behind the nearby Crystal Rig windfarm.Instant grants of up to pound per application will be considered to cover essential expenses.A spokesman said: ldquoOwing to the nature of the crisis, multiple applications from the same inidual or family will be considered as time progresses. Grants above pound may be considered.ldquoAll applications for assistance will be processed as soon as possible, within three to five days.ldquoEast Lammermuir Community Council will, in the future, welcome back any financial assistance-awarded applicants, where they are able to do so.Application forms are available from the grouprsquos website ndash www.eastlammermuircommunitycouncil.org.uk ndash or paper copies can be sought from community councillors.The website also includes details regarding the coronavirus.Mr Bruce said: ldquoI would also say things are ticking over.ldquoIn Oldhamstocks, where I stay, we have had  uses of volunteers.Contact detailsFor assistance, go towww.eastlammermuircommunitycouncil.org.ukGullane. Picture: Google MapsGullaneVOLUNTEERS throughout Gullane have been thanked for their continued support.Gordon McLelland, leader of the villagersquos resilience team, offered his thanks to the volunteers as East Lothian enters a sixth week of lockdown.Kind-hearted volunteers continue to carry out shopping and prescription collection and delivery for a number of Gullane residents, and have followed up referrals from the community centre.Mr McLelland said: ldquoWe have been encouraging people, through our Facebook page, to have food deliveries made direct from the local shops, such as Co-op, Nisa and Aldi, who have been supporting the local community so well.ldquoFood donations from Aldi and the Co-op continue, with any excess being donated to East Lothian Foodbank.ldquoThere has been steady demand for the hearing aid batteries which are now available from the resilience team.ldquoLocal volunteers have established lsquoGullane Scrubbersrsquo, making scrubs and scrub bags for the NHS and care homes.ldquoThe first batch of  scrub wash bags was delivered to the East Lothian Community Hospital.ldquoThe production of over  scrubs trousers is now well underway, with the sample sizes being delivered to the Muirfield care home in Gullane.Meanwhile, on Tuesday, along with food collections, the group is holding an exchange of sanitised books, DVDs, toys and jigsaws in the village hall, with strict separation procedures in place.In addition, there will be on offer lsquoart and craftrsquo packs for children who are in need of materials for play and school work.This will become a weekly event.Contact detailsContact can be made with the resilience group by emailing GullaneRTeam@gmail or phoning  .North Berwick.William Starkey and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons Licence.North BerwickTHE North Berwick Resilience Group fund has donated pound, to pay for visors being made by East Lothian school teachers for frontline workers.The visors are being produced by CDT staff in three East Lothian high schools ndash Preston Lodge, North Berwick High School and Knox Academy.The teams provide this vital equipment free of charge and health workers in North Berwick, including North Berwick Group Practice, care home team and district nurses, have benefited from this access to critical PPE.North Berwick Community Council chairman Judy Lockhart said the high school team have made some , visors and that availability of PPE was absolutely essential to supporting the health service and protecting staff.Gavin Clark, headteacher at Preston Lodge, is co-ordinating the production of masks.Claire Prete, faculty leader for design and technology at North Berwick High School, spent most of her Easter holiday making and distributing visors in North Berwick.Judy said: ldquoThe group operates on a request basis, so any North Berwick team or organisation that feels they need visors are welcome to get in touch with Gavin.All visors are provided for free.Meanwhile, the North Berwick Community Emergency Resilience Team is continuing to shop and collect prescriptions for North Berwick residents who are shielding or self-isolating.One of the teamrsquos street link volunteers, Lisa-Kim Heron, recently embarked on her own initiative making cupcakes to raise money for hand creams for ward teams in the East Lothian Community Hospital in Haddington.Lisa-Kim, who works at the hospital as a social worker, runs her own small business, Sweet Tooth Cakery, by night and at weekends.She sold enough cupcakes to pay for  hand creams.She said: ldquoMy plan is to offer a contactless cupcake drop once a month in and around North Berwick and continue to raise funds for our frontline workers during this time.To contribute to the fund to buy essentials, go to gofundme f northberwick-coronavirus-response-fundContact detailsAnyone needing help with shopping or prescriptions can visit www.nbresilience or phone  .The website also provides lots of useful information for residents, including potential volunteers.IF YOUR resilience group would like to purchase copies of the Courier to deliver to residents who are shielding and unable to leave their homes then please email Courier Editor Robbie Scott via rscott@eastlothiancourier for details. Copies can be delivered to a destination of your choice before being distributed by your volunteers.

title: shop-visit-sting-tail-scorpion-discovered
story: Adrian Nowak, who lives in Musselburgh town centre, found a dead scorpion lying underneath the fruit while out for a recent shopping trip at the supermarket on Newhailes Road."I went to Lidl to get some essentials and I thought about getting melon and found it under one of the melons I picked up - it had been squashed," said Mr Nowak, a chef at a local care home, who bought the melon.A spokesperson for Lidl said: "At Lidl, we pride ourselves on having thorough procedures in place to ensure that our fresh fruit and vegetables are of the highest possible quality for our customers. We are, therefore, disappointed that these expected high standards have not been met on this occasion and would like to sincerely apologise to the customer."We can confirm that it has also been escalated to our Quality Assurance team to investigate further with the supplier."Mr Nowaks photos attracted a lot of interest on social media with one post staying: "I bet you social distanced yourself from that as quickly as possible!"Another read: "When was in Royal Navy we got our stores in foreign ports. Chef checks bananas before go in chilly room, us two stokers there to ensure fridges donrsquot keep tripping. Opens box and spider size of a hand on top unit was alive but, because of being in cool temperatures, it lay still well three guys trying to get up a vertical ladder wasnrsquot easy."One stated: "I was stung by one of them in Guatemala - not pleasant at all."Another said: "Well this story has a sting in the tail.""If you import food from foreign countries its to be expected there are always going to be a few extra guests along for the ride . . . just be alert and be on the lookout, its part of the deal," joked another.

title: costa-coffee-full-list-open-uk-stores---plus-new-rules-customers
story: In an open letter,Jill McDonald, the CEO of the chain, confirmed the reopening of a number of drive-thru stores, plus the introduction of a delivery-only service at a limited amount of other cafes with Uber Eats.What did the CEO say - and what new rules are in place OnFriday Jill McDonald said: "Last week we made the decision to re-open two Drive-Thru lanes and two stores for delivery only in line with the latest Government advice."The safety of our team members and customers is our number one priority and ahead of these stores re-opening, we put in place new social distancing guidelines, enhanced hygiene procedures and are providing teams with personal protective equipment."We have been really pleased with how well our stores teams have been able to adapt to our new ways working, allowing us to serve great coffee, as safely as possible."We have also received some great feedback from our customers and key workers taking advantage of enjoying a well-deserved coffee break whilst on essential journeys to or from work."We will be increasing the number of Drive-Thru lanes and stores open for delivery via Uber Eats from May .""Drive Thrursquosndash Whilst open to all customers, they are intended to offer critical and key workers the chance to enjoy a Costa on essential journeys."Delivery Storesndash No customers will be allowed into the stores but they can order their favourite coffee from the comfort of their own home via Uber Eats, who will deliver."As part of re-opening these additional stores, we are continuing to help support everyone whorsquos keeping the country moving, delivering thousands of our Ready-to-Drink Costa Coffee cans to key workers near those stores re-opening, including hospitals, police and fire stations and NHS call centres."Itrsquos just one of our small tokens of appreciation to the people out there who are giving so much."Whilst most of our stores remain closed we continue to pay our store team members  per title: tesco-doubles-number-home-delivery-slots
story: The move comes amid a surge in demand from customers online.Heres the latest information from Tesco, including how to get one.When lockdown was imposed in March, Tesco was only offering , delivery slots to customers.This figure has since increased to one million, with the supermarket aiming to add another , slots over the next two weeks.To meet this figure, Tesco has recruited an additional , new members of staff to pick and prepare the orders, along with , new drivers to deliver them.The extra effort now means that the supermarket has enough delivery slots available to cover the government-provided list of around , people who are clinically vulnerable and donrsquot have a support network to help them get essential supplies.However, Tesco acknowledged that this number is still ldquonot enough for everyone who feels vulnerable at the moment.Tesco is releasing slots for home delivery online when they become available, but demand is still very high, meaning they are filling up quickly.Shoppers who are able to do so are urged to shop in stores or make use of the click and collect service, so that slots can be prioritised for more vulnerable customers.Click and Collect deliveries can be ordered up to three weeks in advance, and slots will be held for two hours. When this time is nearly up, customers will be prompted so they can extend by a further two hoursneeded.Customers who wish to book a home delivery slot can do so by registering online.Priority slots will first be given to customers across the UK who the government has advised are the most vulnerable. These customers will have received an email from Tesco to let them know they have access to priority booking.Priority delivery slots have an eight-hour delivery window from am to pm, or pm to pm.If you are not a vulnerable customer, you can check for available delivery slots on the Tesco website throughout the day, or select the Click and Collect service when you checkout.Tesco has imposed a limit of  items per order online, with some essential items restricted to a certain amount per customer, such as toilet roll and handwashing products.

title: dunbar-high-street-left-one-bank-tsb-closure

Personally, for me it is quite sad to see it go.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of the townrsquos community council, was keen to see the building brought back into use as soon as possible.She said: ldquoIt is very upsetting because it effects the High Street and people lose that convenience of having a bank within walking distance.A spokesperson for TSB said: ldquoWe have not taken the decision to close our Dunbar branch lightly and recognise concerns about the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, which resulted in an even lower level of footfall in the branch and an uplt in customers registering for online and mobile banking.ldquoWe are contacting customers to help them use other banking options, including telephone and digital, and are working with the Post Office, which is less than a mile away, to ensure our customers can continue to access banking services.Thank you for reading this story. title: ambitious-development-offers-housing-key-workers-planned
story: Early plans for land to the rear of the townrsquos Asda store show retail, office and leisure spaces.The proposals, which are now with East Lothian Council, also include  low-carbon affordable homes for rent, which will be aimed at key workers such as NHS staff, police and care workers.The scheme, which is sandwiched between the East Coast Main Line and the A, will go on display to the public on June .Ken Ross, of Hallhill Developments Ltd, the company behind the plans, told the Courier: ldquoWe are delighted to be bringing forward proposals for our low-carbon community, which we are aiming to be an exemplar development, adopting the latest low-carbon technology.ldquoWe will be undertaking extensive engagement on our proposals and look forward to the involvement of the community in shaping our development.The site surrounds The DunBear sculpture, which was unveiled towards the end of last year.The five-metre-tall sculpture was created by renowned Scottish artist Andy Scott, who was also responsible for the Kelpies, near Falkirk.The sculpture pays tribute to Dunbar-born naturalist John Muir, who is credited with playing a key role in the establishment of national parks around the world.According to the developer: ldquoBuilt on the success of the sculpture, the development will assist in creating jobs and delivering housing for key workers, who have played such a vital role during Covid-. title: mekala-osborne-enjoys-outdoors-road-recovery
story: The image was posted on social media by close family friend Davie Martin, on behalf of the family, who described the image as ldquopeaceful.The caption alongside the image read: ldquoYes its our wee warrior Mekala outside in the hospital grounds for the first time in god knows how long.ldquoSo emotional looking at this just trying to imagine what Mekala is just sitting there thinking about. title: neighbours-dancing-night-away-show-support
story: Tracey Cunningham, , of Lochbridge Road, came up with the idea after seeing a post on social media of people dancing outside.She suggested to her neighbours that they do something similar, and now it has become a weekly tradition for her and other residents.Tracey, a play assistant at North Berwick Playgroup, said: ldquoI saw that someone had shared something and, bearing in mind that Lochbridge Road is a long street, from the top to the bottom, to get all these people out and dancinghellip I thought why donrsquot we all do it up and down the street.ldquoAny excuse for a dance for me!Tonightis the fourth time Tracey and her neighbours will be out dancing. Each week they perform a dferent type of dance so far they have attempted the Slosh, Macarena and Cha Cha Slide.Tonight the children of Lochbridge Road are picking the song.Tracey said: ldquoTraffic has even stopped for us butthey donrsquot want to we will move out of the way and let them pass.ldquoIrsquom trying to get more people to join in but itrsquos been really good so far.ldquoI thought it would be a bit of lighthearted fun because this is such a bad time just now for everyone.ldquoI know a lot of children are getting quite anxious, as are a lot of adults. A couple of my neighbours have said their children are suffering a wee bit and are wondering how long it will be till they see their friends again.ldquoEvensome of the kids donrsquot know the moves,they are dancing along then thatrsquos the whole point.ldquoWe are aware of social distancing so we are making sure everyone keeps their distance.Her daughter Poppy trains at West Lothian Gymnastics Club and during lockdown has been completing her training through Zoom.Her fellow athletes have also joined in with the dancing every week, pausing their training session to do so.Tracey has gathered a list of other dances that can be completed in the weeks ahead and is letting her neighbours pick the next song.

title: seal-pup-spotters-asked-share-photos
story: Zoologist Donald Malone, a former pupil of Stenton Primary and Dunbar Grammar Schools, will send them to friends at the Sea Mammal Research Unitat the University of St Andrews, who keep databases of seal images and attempt to identy iniduals from them.Mr Malone said: ldquoThis would help gain an idea of the number of both harbour and grey seals around the coast of East Lothian.He added: ldquoThey can also keep a lookout for pups, as harbour seals give birth in June and July and grey seals from September to December. Harbour seal pups shed their whitecoat in the womb before being born and so can be in the water and swim almost straight from birth. Females need to give birth on land though.ldquoGrey seal pups are born with the white lunugo fur and have to stay on land much more until they moult this off around three weeks after giving birth.He saidanyone spots a seal entangled in material such as fishing gear, they should contact British Divers Marine Le Rescuebdmlr.org.uk index.php, which has trained people in East Lothian who will try to capture and free the seal.Mr Malone, who studied zoology at University of Glasgow, has been through this training and has had to aid hundreds of seals all over the world.He was delighted to capture on camera a large group of around  seals, some pregnant, near the Musselburgh lagoons while out for his daily exercise on a cycle from his Edinburgh home.They were hauled out on exposed rocks, just offshore and past the lagoons, heading towards Prestonpans.Mr Malone said: ldquoHarbour seal numbers have actually been in quite drastic decline around Scotland, especially on the east coast, so it was good to see this big group of them.ldquoI am a bit of a fan of seals, having worked on numerous projects on them. story: THE Enormous Turnip is a well known story about the importance of working together.I have written a rhyming version of this traditional tale, which has its origins in Russian folklore.I have shared it with teachers and parents in East Lothian and beyond, and have also created a film, which you can find on my YouTube channel, in which I recite the story, with the written words displayed on the screen.The idea is that hopefully children will create a drawing, painting of a scene or character from the story, and send it in.A photo of a scene being acted out would work too.Itrsquos up to the children to use their creativity in any way they want.I will then add these images onto a new version of the film, where I will tell the story using the childrenrsquos artwork.After the summer I hope to turn all the artwork into a book, in which all the pictures made by the children will be included, along with the rhyming story.My hope is that it can be creative fun, but also that both book and the film could be a positive legacy of the lockdown with a well-known story bringing together children who use their imagination to create something together for posterity.If you are a parent, grandparent, teacher or look after children please do get in touch about how to get involved in this project, and I can send materials and links.Or alternatively, you could just read the story at bedtimeyou fancy.The Enormous Turnip In RhymeOnce there was a family who lived together in a wee houseAn old man, an old woman, their grandchildren, a dog, a cat, and a timid mouse.The house had a garden, so wonderful and green,Where the old man grew vegetables, the best yoursquove ever seen.One day he decided, to plant a turnip seed.So he went to his shed, to get the things he would need:A rake and a hoe, and his gardening gloves.Then he went to the garden, a place that he loves.Carrots and radishes already grew there,So he planted the turnip seed. Can you guess where In a patch of ground that was sunny and brightAnd sheltered from the frost that comes during the night.He watered the seed with his watering can,Then waited for it to grow, that gardening old man.And grow it did, that turnip seed,Under the ground, at an incredible speed.Soon bigger than an apple it grew,Then the size of a football, then the size of two.The turnip got bigger with each passing day,How much would it grow  Nobody could say.It grew from big into huge, and then enormous it became.Never in history had there been a turnip quite the same.At last it was ready to title: plans-turn-water-tank-modern-home-given-go-ahead
story: The application received one letter of objection.The approved plans, submitted last year, to turn the more-than--year-old Heugh Reservoir into a liveable property are the second ones to be submitted, after initial ones were withdrawn in .The plans show that the ground floor will consist of a terrace, drawing room, office, guest suite, a fth bedroom with an ensuite bathroom and a plant room, gymnasium and cinema.Upstairs hosts a terrace, the master bedroom and three other bedrooms with all except one having an ensuite bathroom. title: p1-deferrals-u-turn-schools-remain-closed-covid-19
story: Several parents had spoken out in anger after their Primary  deferral funding requests were rejected by the council, which last year had the worst record for approving the applications of any Scottish local authority.This year only two of  applications by parents were approved and of the  refused,  parents appealed.Now the council has said all  cases turned down for funding will be granted the money.However they made it clear the decision was because of the current Covid- pandemic and a review of their policy would be carried out at a later date.One mother told how her children were born two years apart but under the current council policy her youngest son would have had to start P this summer while her oldest, who was born in January, was allowed to defer for a year, was in P.She said: ldquoMy youngest was born at the end of December so they are fully two years apart yet I am not being allowed to defer their start at school and they will be only one year apart in education terms.Current legislation allows parents of children who are born in January and February to automatically receive funding for a delay in starting Primary One until they are five years old.Parents of children born between August and December, who would also start school aged four, can also defer their primary one start for a year but the council can refuse to pay for their nursery care.Last year, East Lothian Council approved  per cent of applications ndash the lowest percentage of any local authority in Scotland. This year the figure fell to less than  per cent.The council also refuses to allow children whose parents opt to keep them home and fund the nursery place themselves to remain in school nurseries.Parents who decide to pay for an additional year of nursery themselves to keep their children out for a year face bills of up to pound, and a hunt for alternative child care places.Another mum who was refused funding said she had initially been supported in her view that her child was too immature to start school by her nursery.But they withdrew that support after pressure from the councilrsquos education department, she said.ldquoThey were told that they couldnrsquot support us because we didnrsquot meet the council policy criteria and withdrew their support, she explained.ldquoOur views meant nothing and the impact on our child meant nothing.And other parents expressed fears that their children were being robbed of nursery experience because they have been in lockdown for some of the vital months they would have had and would have no transition into school.One mum said: Children who start school at -years-old already receive a year less nursery time than those who are older, that has been reduced further by the closure of nurseries.ldquoHow can we ask these young children to go from months at home with their family to suddenly starting primary one with no transition A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoconfirmed they have now agreed to approve all deferral requests for the year ahead.They said: ldquoAs a result of the ongoing closure of schools and nurseries, we have been reviewing applications for deferred entry to P, ahead of session  . Due to the current situation, applications for deferred entry and a further funded year have now been approved. Following the full, national implementation of the expansion of early learning and childcare, we will carry out a review of our wider policy on deferred entry.Thank you for reading this story. title: community-resilience-can-turn-help-dirleton-dunbar-east-linton-east-lammermuir-gullane-north-berwick
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at six of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Dirleton Castle.G Laird and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons Licence.DirletonTHE Dirleton Area Resilience Teamcontinues to serve its community, with requests to pick up shopping and prescriptions still coming in.It has also launched a new booking system to allow it to better serve its community and protect its volunteers.Its essentials community larder continues to flourish and has seen an entertainment section added.It now stocks books, CDs, DVDs and board games, with sections for both adults and children.Generous donations continue to be made of special food items such as crumbles, bakery treats and soups.DART is working with both the Saltire and Hi Awards, youth volunteer programmes that have allowed the group to include volunteering activities for young people.The Saltire Award is available for young people aged -.It is a nationally credited award that goes towards Scottish Credit and Qualications Framework .Volunteers will be allowed to be a part of DART and help complete requests such as delivering leaflets and fulfilling customer orders.The Hi Awards are for children aged five to . DART will be offering children between these ages at-home volunteering opportunities, such as letter writing and art, which will be sent to those self-isolating and shielding in the village.David Tait, lead co-ordinator for DART, said: ldquoWe now have a great opportunity for the youth in our community to feel part of this amazing organisation.ldquoWith the addition of the awards being nationally recognised and accredited, it was a no-brainer to follow through on this opportunity.ldquoIf any of our youth are interested in the Saltire or Hi Awards, please email your enquiry to Dart.Coordinators@outlook.Contact detailsIf you are in need of assistance, contactDART.coordinators@outlookor call .DunbarDunbarA FRIENDLY voice at the other end of the phone is being offered to people on their own during lockdown.Community resilience volunteers in Dunbar are urging people to get in touch evenit is simply for a chat.The townrsquos volunteers are already offering a range of services, including collecting shopping and prescriptions.In addition, there is also a chance for people to simply talk to someone. George Robertson, a member of the townrsquos community council and chairman of the Dunbar and East Linton Area Partnership , stressed the importance of the service.He said: ldquoIt is a really important aspect to the whole thing. I think it will become increasingly important as people get a bit stir crazy.ldquoObviously, a lot of people have friends and family nearby but there are quite a few who do not.ldquoWe need to be conscious that sometimes they are reluctant to ask for help.ldquoWe need to be vigilant for anyone looking for help so we can give a bit of TLC, support, help or a friendly voice on the end of the phone.George has been at the heart of the resilience efforts in the town. Dunbar, along with neighbouring West Barns, has been split into dferent sections, with a lead volunteer in each of the areas.The lead volunteers for the nine clusters ndash Shore and Harbour Group High Street, Parsonspool to Kings Court West End to Countess Road Belhaven and Kirk Park West Barns and the Beveridge Row development Queenrsquos Road and the new housing developments Hallhill, Kellie Road and to the railway line Brodie Road east and north to the railway line and Brodie Road west and north to the railway line ndash have an online meeting each fortnight to checkthere are any issues.George said: ldquoWe are still getting regular requests for shopping, prescriptions and the like.ldquoThere are also a few people who just ring up for a chat.ldquoThat is all ticking along quite nicely.Attention is also turning to how the community copes when lockdown restrictions are relaxed.A number of volunteers willto work as businesses reopen but George was confident that Dunbar and West Barns would continue to be there for people in need.He previously had to draw up a reserve list for volunteers when the coronavirus pandemic started and said there would be enough people to continue to offer support.Contact detailsFor more information, go to Dunbar and District Coronavirus Community Helpers at facebook groups  or Dunbar Community Council at facebook Dunbar CommunityCouncilEast Linton. Picture: Google MapsDunpenderSHOPPING and prescriptions continue to be collected for residents in East Linton and surrounding villages.The Dunpender community resilience team, like many across the county, is offering a iety of services to help people in need during the coronavirus crisis.Judith Priest, chairwoman of the villagersquos community council, said things remained quiet but they were thereanyone was in need of assistance.Contact detailsInformation relating to the coronavirus is available on the Tyninghame Village Hall website ndash tyninghamevillagehall.org.uk ndash as well as on eastlinton.uk.Last month, a flyer was delivered to each home in the area, which offered assistance in terms of shopping, prescriptions or people looking to talk to someone.For more information, call   and  .Stenton.kim traynor and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons Licence.East LammermuirTEAMS of volunteers are keeping in touch with each other throughout East Lothian to ensure they are helping people the best they can.Resilience groups have been set up in towns and villages throughout the county during the coronavirus outbreak.Volunteers have come forward to help vulnerable members of the community with any assistance they need.Chris Bruce, chairman of East Lammermuir Community Council, said they were continuing to work together.The community council covers villages including Spott, Stenton, Innerwick and Oldhamstocks.Mr Bruce said: ldquoThere is a pretty good network of email contact, and people follow up with phone callsthere is something particular.ldquoIt is right across East Lothian and is really good.Contact detailsMore information on the help available in the East Lammermuir area is available from the grouprsquos website, eastlammermuircommunitycouncil.org.uk, which also contains a list of the community councillors.Gullane. Picture: Google MapsGullaneA NEW website has been set up to provide people in Gullane with the latest information relating to the coronavirus.The Gullane Resilience Team, made up of volunteers from throughout the village, have been working hard since the outbreak of restrictions due to the global pandemic.Now, a dedicated website has been set up to keep people up-to-date.A spokesman for the villagersquos resilience team said: ldquoThe Gullane Resilience Team have continued to serve the community but have noticed a settling down of demand.ldquoLorna Scott, our co-ordinator, has worked extremely hard and is developing the village hub for the distribution of food, the exchange of DVDs and childrenrsquos games every Tuesday, noon to pm, and Friday, .am to am.ldquoSeveral face shields were donated by Alun Joseph and were passed on to the Gullane Medical Centre and the Muirfield care home.ldquoBoth have reported that they are delighted with them.ldquoA new website, GullaneRT, has been set up which contains all the information regarding how our resources are being deployed and the services that can be provided by the team.Contact detailsFor more information, visit www.gullanert or contact the team on GullaneRteam@gmail or by telephoning  .North Berwick.William Starkey and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons Licence.North BerwickNORTH Berwick Day Centre may be closed to its members due to the coronavirus crisis, but it is making sure they are being looked after in their homes.Some  of the day centrersquos  members are receiving sandwich lunches.The centre was established  years ago to improve the quality of le for older people who live independently in and around North Berwick.Normally, members would be brought to the centre by its own specially adapted bus once or twice a week.Now, its nine staff are delivering  lunches, five days a week, and all members are also getting free copies of the East Lothian Courier, thanks to the North Berwick resilience group fund.Care assistant Lisa Robertson said a lot of members were getting their lunch every day and those celebrating birthdays were also getting a special treat.In the past eight weeks, five members have received sweet treats to celebrate their birthdays, with the most recent being a -year-old woman.The Day Centre is also handing out quizzes, games and jigsaws to members, as well as having a chat on doorsteps ndash at a safe distance ndash where possible.Lisa said so far all of the centre members have stayed in good health but they are lonely and missing meeting other people.A team of around  volunteers are contacting members by telephone to have a chat and also find outany other help is needed.Meanwhile, North Berwick Community Councilrsquos resilience group fund is being used to help volunteers get ready-made meals delivered to vulnerable residents in the town three days per week.Community council chair Judy Lockhart has arranged for voluntary organisation Home-Start East Lothian to provide two-course meals at a cost of pound. a day, and is using the fund to subsidise them for people wanting a meal every day of the week.As a result, someone wanting seven meals a week will only have to pay pound.The resilience fund can also offer financial assistance to those who need money to pay for these meals.Contact detailsPeople wishing to sign up for the service should phone the resilience group helpline on   or email communityresilience@northberwickcommunitycouncil.org.ukOr you can visitwww.nbresilience

title: community-resilience-can-turn-help-garvald-gifford-haddington-macmerry-gladsmuir-pencaitland-tranent-elphinstone
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at six of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Garvald.M J Richardson and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons Licence.GarvaldCOMMUNITY spirit has been praised in a rural part of East Lothian which is tackling the coronavirus.Garvald and Morham Community Council was one of the first to produce an emergency resilience plan, with the Garvald Emergency Resilience Team also being established.Since then, a leaflet has been hand delivered to each of the properties, with information also put online to keep people up-to-date with what is happening.Penny Short, co-ordinator of the Garvald Emergency Resilience Team, noted there were a number of issues they had to overcome, including the remoteness of some people living in the area.She said: ldquoBefore the coronavirus epidemic and subsequent lockdown hit we had already hand delivered a leaflet to every address in our ward explaining who we were and what the team could do, so that everyone in our area knew who to contactthey needed any help.ldquoOur team members have a WhatsApp Group and we keep in touch through that.ldquoSocial media has been a blessing through this time of social distancing!ldquoOnce lockdown was in place I set up a private Facebook page called Garvald Community which is for residents only.ldquoThis is a safe, supportive place where people can ask for help or assistance and hopefully find helpful advice and information such as messages from the government or information on food deliveries.ldquoInformation on food deliveries is pretty important as Garvald doesnrsquot have any shopsand for people who are self-isolating or shielding these food deliveries are essential.ldquoWe contacted ious food suppliers and co-ordinated delivery days and then passed on the details to the villagers.However, it is not just through social media that the group has reached out to people.An online form, which people can fill in outlining how they need assistance, is available on the villagersquos website.Penny added: ldquoWe are aware of any vulnerable people in our area and we are connected with our residents ndash whether through the Garvald Community Facebook page, the website or the villagersquos Neighbourhood Watch Scheme.ldquoBecause we are pretty remote and used to being cut off in bad weather our community is already pretty resilient and has always been supportive to everyone in the village.ldquoBut our wonderful community spirit has never been more evident than right now as everyone has come together to help each other and provide support with shopping, collecting prescriptions, offers of dog walking and other ways to help each other.ldquoWe have recently launched a group to make face masks for locals and lsquoscrubs bagsrsquo for NHS and care workers.ldquoNot for the first time I am so grateful to stay in Garvald and so proud of our fantastic community."Contact detailsFor more information, go to www.garvald.org.ukGford. Picture: Google MapsGfordGIFFORD volunteers this week trialled a new Soup And A Smile delivery service as they took hot lentil soup, a buttered roll and a fruit scone to households where there are older residents living alone.The plan is to provide lunch one day a week, as well as catch up with residents while observing social distancing rules.Nicola Goddard, from Lanterne Rouge cafeacute, offered her services to support the volunteer activity, which is provided free to the households.A spokesperson for Gford Community Council said: ldquoThe feedback is already very positive both regarding the fabulous quality of the food and the concept.ldquoOur delivery team worked quickly and observed all protocols to deliver the food to households. Wersquore gathering more feedback as we look to provide this on a weekly basis.This week, the team has also been sourcing face coverings for volunteers, to offer them extra confidence when undertaking tasks on behalf of households.Lanterne Rouge donated a supply of lsquobuffsrsquo and local resident and designer Ellie Thomson is making the coverings from her home.The community council said a request for cotton fabric, thread and elastic generated a fantastic response and they are currently trying to source additional elastic.They have also written to Homes For Le Housing Partnership, which oversees social housing flats in the village, after discovering families living there were unable to use their drying greens as gardens.They said: ldquoWe are very lucky in Gford to have a lot of open green space surrounding us.ldquoWe became aware through some tenants in social housing flats that they are unable to use drying greens as garden space for their children.ldquoWe have written to Homes For Le to ask that this situation is revisited so all children can have access to safe outdoor space on their doorstep.ldquoWe received a positive response from the organisation and hope that the guidance can be claried to benefit families in the village.Contact detailsAnyone needing help can contact: Jo Allen, GCC chair, on   or ChairGfordCC@gmail Adam White, GCC vice chair, on   or adamjswhite@outlook Wendy Ferguson, GCC treasurer, on   or wendyferguson.wf@gmail Aniko Schuetz Bradwell, minister, on   or aschuetzbradwell@churchofscotland.org.ukHaddingtonHaddingtonRESILIENCE volunteers are looking to the future to ensure people continue to receive assistance once lockdown restrictions are relaxed.A squad of volunteers in Haddington have been helping with everything from plans together for coming out of quarantine.ldquoFor a lot of us in the coming weeks, we will be coming out of lockdown but for our elderly residents they will probably still be in lockdown.ldquoWe are starting to plan to make sure everybody is taken care of post lockdown.Currently, many of the volunteers are off their work and able to help throughout the town.However, as businesses reopen and peopleto work, it reduces the amount of free time people have.Chris said it was important to ensure there were still volunteers available to help people who continued to be at home.The group experienced an increase in calls in the last week, with the community council vice-chairman putting it down to many people reaching the end of the month in terms of their wages.He said: ldquoFor some folk it was the end of the month and we were getting an increase in calls about food.ldquoWe have done a few things over the weekend and a couple of things to make sure people have good food, that they are covered and they are not starving themselves.Chris praised the efforts of Our Community Kitchen, who are based in the townrsquos bowling club.The team of volunteers are delivering hot meals to people throughout the town to ensure no-one is going hungry.One other issue Chris pointed to was the increased need in terms of help with gardening.He added: ldquoWith the rain and sunshine over the past week, peoplersquos gardens have started growing.ldquoWe have got in touch with some gardeners, who are going out to help people this week.Contact detailsFor more information, go to
