Picture: Google MapsMacmerry and GladsmuirTHE Macmerry and Gladsmuir Community Resilience Team are encouraging local residents to continue making pom poms, and are on the lookout for more supplies.In the past two weeks,  craft packs containing equipment necessary to make the pom poms have been distributed, with a number of adults joining in alongside the villagesrsquo children.Stevie Sutherland, one of the resilience co-ordinators, told the Courier that volunteers have put ribbons up along the school gates for people to hang their finished pom poms from.He said: ldquoWersquove had about  packs handed out already and people have started making them.ldquoPeople are encouraged to go along to the school and tie their pom poms to the ribbons.He added: ldquoSince itrsquos started itrsquos become quite colourful and is really nice to see.ldquoThe whole point is to show off community support it will also show and encourage people who are from Macmerry or travelling through that we are supporting frontline workers, whether that be from the NHS, emergency service workers or supermarket staff.ldquoWe are trying to bring back that feel-good factor into the villages, when all we seem to have is bad news.One resident has decided to hang plastic balls of dferent colours outside her house as part of the project.Anyone willing to donate wool, of any quality although double knit is preferred, or anyone needing assistance is asked to call  .Collection or pick up of wool donations can also be arranged.Meanwhile, the resilience team were joined by a couple of new volunteers in the past week, and they will help to deliver the continuing resilience effort.Stevie said the resilience group have put together a contingency plan, should the virusin the future, which will allow the effort to start back up again more quickly and smoothly.He said: ldquoWersquove put a kind of plan in place, forthis all goes away then comes back again.ldquoWe now have an admin system that could be started upneeded.Contact detailsMore information is available on the resilience grouprsquos Facebook and Twitter pages, atfacebook groups   andtwitter MacmerryTeamPencaitland. Picture: Google MapsPencaitlandTHE response from residents in Pencaitland and its surrounding area to an appeal for volunteers has been described as ldquophenomenal by community council chairman Ralph Averbuch.Before lockdown had even been introduced, Pencaitland Community Council was preparing for what was coming with an early call for help.Now they have  volunteers working in a resilience network of support for the communityrsquos most vulnerable families and residents.Ralph said: ldquoOn March , it was already looking like we were approaching unprecedented events in modern times.ldquoIt was still a week away from local schools being closed and social distancing really kicking in however, unprecedented times require unprecedented measures and in Pencaitland and District that involved a call for volunteers.ldquoWe needed to be ready, and quickly, for whatever was coming.ldquoMost calls for community participation in ordinary times generate next to no response.ldquoPeople are busy with their own lives and family work concerns so lsquocommunityrsquo, for most, almost always takes a back seat.ldquoYet, when the call went out for volunteers, the response was nothing short of phenomenal.ldquoWithin  hours we had  people signed up and ready to do whatever needed to be done.ldquoFrom this start, we were able to begin a process of organising volunteers into geographic clusters, each with their own lead co-ordinators.ldquoNothing like this has happened in any of our letimes, yet, when the situation really demanded that people step up and be counted, there was no shortage of volunteers willing and able to help, from people in their teens to those in their s.ldquoWe are now a resilience network of . Had I been asked at the start how many people would come forward Irsquod have thought Irsquod be able to count them on one hand.ldquoThe good news is when itrsquos really important and people know it, there is no shortage of volunteers wanting to help solve our problems.Contact detailsAnyone living in or around the Pencaitland area and seeking assistance, or just wanting to help out, in the first instance can call Community Council chair Ralph on   or email him at covid@pencaitland.org.Additionally, Pencaitland  District Coronavirus Emergency Helpers have a Facebook page ndash facebook groups   ndash where you can get in touchyou want to help with the massive volunteer effort.Tranent. Picture: Google MapsTranent and ElphinstoneTRANENT and Elphinstone Community Council is starting to think about how it will continue delivering its resilience effort once lockdown restrictions start to be relaxed.Member Mike Falconer is the grouprsquos single point of contact and is overseeing the local resilience effort.He told the Courier that, once restrictions begin to lt, people will still need support so the resilience effort will still be needed, something he said could be described as ldquocontingency planning.He said: ldquoWe canrsquot just stop the need is still going to be there.ldquoThe lt of restrictions is going to be gradual [rather than all at once] and we need to think how we are going to manage and maintain the resilience effort and some sort of support.He added that there is not a plan in place, as such, but the community council ldquohas got its eye on it.Meanwhile, it is business as usual and residents who need assistance continue to get the help they need.Mike said: ldquoItrsquos exactly the same and we are carrying on doing what we are doing, delivering food, walking dogs and picking up prescriptions.ldquoWersquove got a routine established and are just carrying on delivering it until we are told to stop.The resilience effort is also helping Fundamental Foods and the Pennypit Trust with food deliveries, as well as assisting with its school hub effort.Contact detailsThose who need assistance can call   or email tranentemergencyresponse@gmail

title: community-resilience-can-turn-help-cockenzie-port-seton-humbie-east-west-saltoun-bolton-longniddry-musselburgh-prestonpans
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at five of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Cockenzie and Port Seton. Picture: Google MapsCockenzie and Port SetonTHE resilience team in Cockenzie  Port Seton continue to help local residents, and more than pound, has been donated to the cause by iniduals and groups since lockdown began.The resilience effort is being led by Cockenzie  Port Seton Community Council, whose chairman, Bryan Hickman, said: ldquoPeople have been so generous and the money is being used to purchase food.Some of the grouprsquos volunteers are asking for donations of wool, to make blankets which will be given to the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh and used for premature babies.To donate items, contact Cockenzie  Port Seton Community Council via email at cockenzieandportseton@hotmail.The resilience group has received a donation from the Walk With Scott Foundation and will deliver craft activity packs alongside its breakfast packs on Wednesdays, helping to keep local residents entertained while at home.To mark VE Day and allow residents to celebrate in lockdown, afternoon tea boxes consisting of items such as sandwiches, scones, cakes and tea will be delivered.Bryan is also keen to get copies of the Courier delivered to elderly and vulnerable residents, as groups in Haddington and North Berwick are doing.The community councilrsquos resilience team are also sending out hot meals and providing food packs to local children who would usually receive free school meals.This is being run from the Port Seton Centre, supported by centre staff.So far,  lunches and  breakfast packs are going out every day.More than , meals are going out to the local community every week.Last week, the centre started receiving a delivery from FareShare, a charity that delivers surplus food from supermarkets to charities and organisations for those in need.Contact detailsAnyone who needs assistance can call the resilience emergency number on  .East Saltoun. Picture: Google MapsHumbie, East and West Saltoun, and BoltonRESIDENTS of four rural villages are being reminded help is there for themthey need it.Contacts have been set up in Humbie, East and West Saltoun, and Bolton to offer people assistance during the coronavirus pandemic.Shena Jamieson, who lives in Bolton, told the Courier it had been reasonably quiet in terms of the number of calls but stressed they were there to help.She said: ldquoPeople should ring us.ldquoDonrsquot feel that you are being a nuisance or wonder whether it is the right person.ldquoWe can always put you in touch with the right person.Contact detailsPeople in Bolton should contact Shena Jamieson on   or by email at shenajamieson@aol.East Saltoun residents can contact Buffy Neilson on   or buffyneilson@yahoo.In West Saltoun, Derek Smith is the point of contact on   or by emailing coruisk@gmail.Finally, in Humbie, people are encouraged to call Margo Hodge on   or email humbiehelp@gmailLongniddry. Picture: Google MapsLongniddryITrsquoS business as usual for the resilience effort in Longniddry which is being led by the local church and supported by Longniddry Community Council.SheilaJamieson said she is still receiving some queries, such as people with toothache asking the best place to get help.She added that there have not been many shopping requests, as a lot of residents are getting their food through online deliveries.Sheila said: ldquoAlthough we do have quite a lot of older people, we are quite fortunate to have a great community.ldquoVolunteers are also helping their neighbours and friends along with enquiries as they come in.ldquoItrsquos pretty steady and we are just going on as normal.One Longniddry resident has started offering a dogwalking service for those unable to take their pooch on its daily stroll.Those interested should contact Danni Anderson on Facebook.Volunteers are happy to pick up prescriptions, though the local pharmacy offers a delivery service to those aged  and over.Contact detailsThose who need any help or assistance are asked to call Sheila Jamieson on  .Musselburgh. Picture: Google MapsMusselburghRESILIENT Musselburgh has nearly hit the  mark with the number of volunteers who have joined its emergency efforts during the Covid- pandemic.The co-ordinating team have now settled into their new base at the Musselburgh East Community Learning Centre, after their recent move from Pinkie St Peterrsquos Primary School.Distribution of food and prescriptions to the communities of Musselburgh, Wallyford, Whitecraig and Old Craighall is continuing.Local residents are being supported through referrals from the East Lothian Council Contact Centre and callsto the Resilient Musselburgh dedicated phone number on  .Last week alone,  preschool lunch packs,  meals and  lunches were distributed.Up until last Friday,  soup and sandwich deliveries were made thanks to the Mercat Grill in Whitecraig, which started the initiative on April .Musselburgh Area Partnership, working in partnership with Hickory, started distributing meals on April  and, so far, they have provided  meals to vulnerable people in the local community.Irene Tait, chairperson of Musselburgh  Inveresk Community Council, who is co-ordinating the volunteer response, said: ldquoIt is so heartening to see the willingness and effort given to the community by the volunteers.ldquoThey have happily gone over and above by uplting and delivering repeat prescriptions from ious locations, including uplts from outside Musselburgh, and are continuing to deliver emergency food packs and pre-school lunches.ldquoWithout them the community response would not happen.Contact detailsThe Resilient Musselburgh dedicated support number is  .Prestonpans. Picture: Google MapsPrestonpansPRESTONPANS Community Council has established a hardship fund for people who are struggling as the lockdown continues.Community council chairman Brian Weddell said last week had been the busiest yet for the resilience team, with volunteers managing to deliver leaflets throughout the Pans advertising the Scotmid free shopping delivery service, and several volunteers now doing daily dog walks for local people self isolating.More of the volunteers are also helping the work at the Pennypit Pantry by collecting groceries being donated by local supermarkets and delivering meals to local people.Last week, the Pantry provided  meals to a mix of elderly residents who are shielding and many families looking after young children currently off school.While demand for support has been high, anyone needing help should contact the Pennypit Pantry on   or email lornabellany@gmailThe hardship fund has been established for people finding it increasingly dficult as the lockdown continues, and anyone needing help should telephone   or email prestonpansresilience@gmailRegular information is also posted on both the Prestonpans Community Council Facebook page or their dedicated Prestonpans Resilience Facebook page.Brian said: ldquoOur resilience team are also grateful for the support we are receiving from Sandy Baptie and Kevin Sewell in East Lothian Councilrsquos Resilient Communities team, who send out daily updates which provide useful information on what is happening in other resilience teams and the additional support that is available.Contact detailsIf anyone needs help, they should telephone   or emailprestonpansresilience@gmail

title: marking-75-years-since-ve-day
story: The Bank Holiday was moved from Mondayto today , to allow people to celebrate.In East Lothian, council staff and schools were granted an additional dayrsquos leave to allow them to mark the occasion.Many events and commemorations initially scheduled have had to be cancelled or scaled back due to the ongoing coronavirus outbreak and subsequent lockdown, with people unable to come together, celebrate, remember and give thanks in person.Some of the commemorations taking place today include a two-minute silence at am, playing of the Last Post at .pm and the Nations Toast at pm, in whicheveryone is asked to raise a glass and toast the heroes of World War Two.East Lothianrsquos Lord Lieutenant Michael Williams has also suggested ways people can remember the day.He said: ldquoGiven the current global pandemic crisis we face due to Covid-, many of the planned celebrations and acts of remembrance planned across East Lothian have been cancelled or changed to reflect the need to keep the nation safe.ldquoHowever, commemorating this historic event from home or the work place is still encouraged as best as we can.ldquoIt can be a time for everyone in East Lothian to remember the immeasurable sacrices that were made at home and abroad and to celebrate  years of victory and peace in Europe.Some of these activities include the thousand plus pipers taking part on Battlersquos Orsquoer at pm, town criers, and members of the public,crying out for peace at .pm and the Queenrsquos televised address at pm, the same time her father King George VI gave a radio address  years ago.The Battles Oer event sees thousands of pipers performing the song, traditionally played at the end of a battle.As well as the cry for peace, bells in churches and cathedrals will ring at pm in a collective celebration of peace.Mr Williams also highlighted several VE Day television shows, the list can be viewed at spark.adobe page eceXXfFlyGV The Royal British Legion has also created a programme of activities, including a livestream on Facebook .am-noon and an evening of music and memories in partnership with BBC from pm.Councillor Jim Goodfellow, East Lothian Councilrsquos Armed Forces Champion, said: ldquoIt is hard to imagine the experiences and sacrices that were made during wartime on our behalf.ldquoHowever I believe that our current perspective will give us an even greater appreciation for those who served and supported the war effort and their communities who prayed, and mourned their loved ones.ldquoWhile our commemorations may be dferent to previous years, and to those that were originally envisaged, they will be no less heartfelt and sincere.Meanwhile, East Lothian Council and its community planning partners have signed a covenant to support the armed forces community living in the county.It is an agreement between the council, the community planning partnership and armed forces community in East Lothian.It recognises the issues experienced by the armed forces community locally and is a commitment to work together to address them.

title: seek-help-medical-emergencies
story: YESTERDAY, May , marked the th anniversary of VEDay, remembering the surrender of the Nazis and the end of the Second World War.I hope you joined me in paying tribute to surviving veterans and in commemorating those lost during the conflict.I am very grateful for the enduring peace achieved across Europe since .Although we might not have been able to take part in our usual commemorations, there was an online service led by Legion Scotland and Poppyscotland, which included a message from children and families currently learning at home and a video message of thanks from the First Minister.I am glad that measures were taken to honour this important anniversary, and to remember those who lost their lives.There has been a large reduction in the number of stroke patients, with AEs and stroke wards signicantly quieter since the beginning of the Covid- pandemic.We must not forget that a stroke is a medical emergency and,you see someone displaying stroke symptoms, it is still important to immediately dial .This is not the only medical emergency that you should seek support on ndashyou have any urgent symptoms that are not coronavirus related, you should still seek assistance from a GP or hospital.The NHS is still here for us and will continue to support those who need it.The Scottish Government has recommended thatyou are in an enclosed public space, such as a supermarket, then you should consider using something to cover your face.As well as this, you must also maintain a two-metre distance from those outside your household.It is important to note that covering your face does not necessarily mean that you need a medical grade face mask ndash something such as a scarf would also suffice.As we continue working together to overcome the Covid- pandemic, it is important that we continue to take social distancing measures seriously and I would recommend keeping up to date with the Scottish Government and NHS advice.

title: must-return-fairer-world-says-mp
story: MINDS are turning to le post-coronavirus, though itrsquoll still be a while before lockdown is even partially lted. But some of the enforced changes have suited some.Irsquove a few friends nearing retirement age and, enjoying the change in pace of le, have decided to retire early. It doesnrsquot suit everyone and itrsquos not available for many but, for those to whom it does apply, I say good luck.But there are other aspects that apply to us all. The Irish President, Michael D Higgins, made a remarkable speech about how both a better country and a fairer world need to come from this. Those sentiments and that ambition must apply here, as well as across the Irish Sea.When this is over, itrsquos about rewarding fairly those who have, not just throughout this crisis but always, worked hard in dficult circumstances.Itrsquos decent pay and conditions, as much as applause, that NHS staff, carers and council workers deserve. Despite the rhetoric about all of us being in this together, the poor have been suffering the most and that too must change.As well as in our economy and society though, the change must also be in our natural environment. Theof wildle has been joyful and the improvement in air quality a revelation.The latterrsquos something wersquove often taken for granted but for those with a lung or heart problem itrsquos a daily concern.The images of pollution fading across countries is astonishing but the freshness wersquore feeling in our lungs is something we need to retain.We canrsquot simply go back to le the way it was. When the coronavirus crisis is over, the climate change crisis will remain.We need to cherish the improvements that have come about, but remember the huge challenges that still exist, in ensuring our planetrsquos habitable for future generations.It wonrsquot be either easy or simple but the sacrices made by so many and the limited pleasures wersquove had as a result of it, must be a spur to deliver that better country and fairer world.

title: former-power-station-site-become-covid-19-testing-centre
story: East Lothian Council has confirmed that the former Cockenzie Power Station site will be opened and operated by the military as part of the UK Governments Covid- testing programme.No date for when it will start operations has been revealed but it is likely to be within the next week as testing is ramped up as part of plans to ease the current lockdown.It will be the first Covid- testing site of its kind in East Lothian, where an assessment centre has also been operating in Musselburgh since the start of April.The site, which was bought by the local authority from ScottishPower and is currently being marketed for economic investment, was offered up as a potential testing location by the council.The unit will be managed and staffed by military personnel, who would be responsible for its safe operation.Military staff will make appropriate use of PPE and no equipment will be left on site whilst the facility is closed.The council said it expects the facility to operate as a self-contained, drive-through facility. People will remain in their vehicle whilst being tested. Initially, it is understood it would operate over two, three-day periods.Tom Reid, the councils head of infrastructure, said: ldquoWe were asked to identy a potentially suitable site for a drive-through, mobile testing facility to be located."The former Cockenzie Power Station site was identied as a site which could be operated safely by military personnel."This facility would enable key workers who are self-isolating due to them or household members displaying symptoms to undergo testing, which is a vital component of the national response to tackling Covid-."East Lothian Council will continue to play its part and work with partners locally and nationally in dealing with the challenges posed by the emergency.The facility will provide tests for key workers who are self-isolating due to them or household members displaying symptoms.It is understood key workers and their family members will be eligible for testing.Key workers who are, or have a family member who is, symptomatic, can sign up via thehttps:self-referral.test-for-coronavirus.service.gov.uk portal.Cockenzie power stations famous twin chimneys were demolished in a controlled explosion in September, , two years after it had closed. The power station had opened in .

title: costa-coffee-starbucks-mcdonalds-get-green-light-reopen-drive-thrus
story: Ahead of an anticipated relaxation of the lockdown rules, the Environment Secretary has said drive-thru restaurants such as McDonaldrsquos are ldquomade for social distancing.At the Downing Street press conference on Friday, George Eustice said it was safe for takeaway food shops to reopen.Many familiar high street chains including McDonaldrsquos, Greggs and KFC chose to shut their doors during the lockdown.What did the Environment Secretary say When asked about fast-food stores reopening, Mr Eustice said: ldquoI think our view is that probably a McDonaldrsquos drive-thru is made for the social distancing situation we are in, in that people do not leave their car, they place their order and someone passes a bag of food to them at the end through a kiosk.Unlike many other businesses, fast-food outlets were not mandated to close during the lockdown.Some chains have begun to reopenSome restaurants have begun the process of reopening, with KFC opening around  of its branches for delivery or drive-thru.McDonaldrsquos has conducted trials on reopening stores, with  restaurants opening for deliveries from next week.Askedoutlets could have stayed open during the crisis, Mr Eustice said: ldquoWhile clearly restaurants and pubs had to close, we were quite keen to keep that capacity to be able to do takeaway food for people.He suggested reduced footfall in town centres, staff anxiety and a sense of what was ldquosocially acceptable given the stay-at-home message had led to places such as McDonaldrsquos and KFC closing.Mr Eustice added: ldquoI think it is quite possible for these venues to reopen and reopen safely, we never mandated that they should close.ldquoI think some of those food-to-go businesses will probably be seeking to learn lessons from what supermarkets have done as they consider tentatively reopening.New safety measures have been introduced at food outletsBefore reopening, the McDonaldrsquos restaurants will be deep cleaned, while new safety measures will be introduced such as Perspex screens and floor markings.Staff will also receive protective equipment, such as non-medical grade face masks, and have their temperatures taken with ldquocontactless thermometers before shts.Earlier this month Greggs pulled back on plans to reopen its first sites to the public next week over fears it could attract crowds.The highly popular bakery chain announced it would carry out the opening trial behind closed doors over fears customers will flock in large numbers.

title: itv-reveal-run-episodes-emmerdale-coronation-street
story: It comes after the number of shows broadcast each week were cut back to make the bank of recorded episodes last longer after production on both soaps was suspended in March.When are episodes We will be very careful and mindful about that sort of thing.Lygo said that while viewership is up in daytime, it is not up in peak time and he is worried about shedding viewers over the summer when the schedule is filled with repeats.He said this is why he is particularly anxious to get the soaps back on air, adding: ldquoI donrsquot want anyone who has been watching the soaps for years thinking lsquoOh I have done without it, maybe Irsquoll detox and Irsquoll get some le backrsquo.ldquoNo. Please donrsquot do that. title: ryanairs-new-passenger-rules-airline-plans-restart-some-flights-july

title: east-lothian-council-racing-june
story: Groundstaff at the townrsquos award-winning racecourse, who have been furloughed, will temporarily resume work this month to prepare the track for the anticipated fixture.Bill Farnsworth, general manager, said that the racecourse was using the next few weeks to prepare after the UK Government said no sporting events woulduntil June  and the Scottish Government continued lockdown until the end of May.He said: ldquoThe British Horseracing Industry has already done much work on the operational plan for the resumption of horseracing in the UK.ldquoWe will therefore use the forthcoming weeks to finalise the plan for ato racing at Musselburgh, hopefully in June, however horseracing will only resume at Musselburgh when it is safe to do so and with the full support of the UK and Scottish Governments.Mr Farnsworth said that racingrsquoswould be under strict restrictions and behind closed doors, similar to what is already happening in France and Germany.He said the hope is that Musselburgh can resume its schedule fixture list with a race on June , which had already been in its diary.He said: ldquoIf horseracing resumes in June, we hope to stage Musselburghrsquos scheduled fixture on Saturday thJune butthe advice is that June is too early to stage horseracing in Scotland, we will wait until for the appropriate time and for the greenlight from the UK and Scottish Governments.Horse-racing ed in France this week giving hope to trainers that Britain will not be far behind.A joint letter to Scottish Sports Minister Joe Fitzpatrick, MSP, from East Lothian MP Kenny MacAskill and MPs Allan Dorans, Angela Crawley and Pete Wishart, who represent racecourses in Hanmilton, Ayr and Perth urges a quick restart to racing when safe to do so.It says: ldquoRacing finds be able to come back on shorter notice than the human athletes inother sports.ldquoWhen it is safe to do so, ato racing is the best way of getting the economic cogs of theindustry turning once more, and kickstart the benefits to the Scottish economy that horseracingbrings, even in a behind closed doors environment.ldquoTherefore, we ask that you please accelerateyour talks with Scottish racing to ensure that a risk managedcan take place as soon aspossible and that ato racing behind closed doors in Scotland does not get unduly delayedcompared to the rest of the United Kingdom.

title: furlough-extended-october-questions-answered
story: But what does it all mean for workers and businesses Heres what you need to know.What will happen to workers on furlough Mr Sunak said they will continue to receive  per centof their pay ndash up to pound, a month ndash until the end of October.This extends the original furlough scheme to eight months since it was launched in March.The Chancellor also said there will be the possibility of part-time s for staff from August, pointing out that manufacturers have been asking for staggered shts to reopen production lines.Are there more details on part-time s and can I take a job where The details will be published later this month, but Mr Sunak stressed to MPs that furloughed workers can take jobs where while on the scheme.Government advice says: ldquoIf your contract allows, you may undertake other employment while your current employer has placed you on furlough, and this will not affect the grant that they can claim under the scheme.However, staff cannot work for their employer while furloughed.Will the Government continue covering the cost The Government will fund the furlough scheme, which has supported seven million jobs at a cost of pound billion a month, until the end of July.After that, companies will be expected to make a contribution to the payments, although the amount workers take home will not fall below the  per cent mark.How much will businesses be expected to pay towards furlough The details will be published later this month, the Chancellor said, but it is likely to be judged on a sector-by-sector basis, similar to the details published on Monday by the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategyfor companies looking to reopen under new ldquoCovid Secure measures.With certain sectors ing to some normality, others, including restaurants and gyms, remain unlikely to reopen fully for several months.Can we expect to see furlough extended beyond October The Government has said it will continue to monitor the situation and is willing to adjust advice accordingly.But Mr Sunak made clear it is unlikely to be extended.He told the Commons: ldquoWe will keep everything under review but my expectation is by thenthe scheme should end. Wersquove stretched and strained to be as generous as possible to businesses and workers, which is why we have made the decision that wersquove made today.The Chancellor added: ldquoBut hellip this scheme is expensive. Itrsquos the right thing to do. The cost of not acting would have been far higher but itrsquos not something that can continue indefinitely into the future. Eight months of total support is a considerable amount of time.Are there any other signicant changes to the furlough scheme More details will come this month, but MPs raised concerns from self-employed workers who pay themselves via idends, asking whether they would be able to receive further support.However, Mr Sunak insisted current support is strong enough.Why is the Government announcing the extension now Under employment laws, companies must start informing any staff they plan to make redundant within  days of any changes.The previous furlough scheme was due to end by July, meaning consultations would need to begin imminently, but the extension to October will address it.

title: skyes-limit-sabhal-mor-ostaig---unique-gaelic-only-college-set-stunning-island-location
story: Situated in the stunningly beautul peninsula of Sleat in the south end of the island, Sabhal Mograver Ostaig is a unique Gaelic-only environment and the only college of its kind offering further and higher education through the medium of the language.The college offers a range of provision from beginnersrsquo courses to a PhD, with the flexibility of studying part-time or full-time, on campus or via distance learning. At a crucial time in the survival of the language, graduates have helped create a Gaelic speaking workforce that now holds key posts across a wide range of sectors in Scotland.Sabhal Mograver Ostaig is one of the key partners in fulfilling the governmentrsquos objectives in the National Gaelic Plan, which aims to increase the number of people speaking the language and accelerate the growth of Gaelic.Many people are keen to learn more about the language because of its rich culture and the college provides a wide range of short courses in Gaelic language, song and traditional music. Ceilidhs, workshops, conversation circles and music sessions all create an encouraging atmosphere that bring together students from  countries across five continents.As a modern, innovative college, Sabhal Mograver Ostaig has excellent learning resources on campus including an exceptional library collection, residential student accommodation, broadcast and recording facilities and a Gaelic medium childcare facility on site. It also has a growing international reputation for academic research.The college was founded on the principle of being part of the local and wider community and its activities are greatly enhanced by co-operative links, being home to a number of signicant national creative and cultural projects such as Tobar an Dualchais, Ainmean Agraveite na h-Alba and Cagravenan Graphics Studio. It plays a leading role in the promotion of the Gaelic arts and culture and also offers an international exchange programme with universities in Canada and Ireland.The collegersquos graduates include Seumas Greumach , Chief Executive of An Comunn Gaidhealach, which runs the Royal National Mod, who studied the Cugraversa Comais in  and then ed for another year to study Cagravenan is Cultar na Gagraveidhlig. He went to Sabhal Mograver to improve his language skills and says he would not hold his present job had he not become a fluent speaker.ldquoI was fully immersed in the language at Sabhal Mograver Ostaig, which is essential to become fluent in any language. he says. ldquoYou could hear Gaelic being spoken every day, in every situation and that helped me no end in improving my own Gaelic. I gained a great deal of confidence in terms of Gaelic grammar, spelling and writing, all of which has been invaluable in my working le.BBC weather presenter, Joy Dunlop, is another graduate of the college who says the fluency in Gaelic she developed at the college has given her many opportunities that she otherwise would not have had.She studied Gaelic as a second language when she was a pupil at Oban High School then decided to do her sixth year at the college. She initially planned to stay for just one year to do the Cugraversa Comais but loved it so much she stayed for four, graduating with a BAin Cagravenan agus Cultar na Gagraveidhlig .ldquoAttending Sabhal Mograver was a revelation for me, she says. ldquoThe education I received was unparalleled.ldquoThe personal support and guidance I received from all the staff was of the highest level and I always felt that our teachers were genuinely invested in both the language itself and our progress.ldquoBeing immersed in the language is definitely the best way to learn, dficult as it could be at times, and having the opportunity to speak Gaelic in both the classes and the community was a real help to me.ldquoSimply,you genuinely want to learn Gaelic, there is no better place to do so than Sabhal Mograver Ostaig. Tha i math agus tha i math dhut!

title: coronavirus-scotland-enjoy-cairngorms-comfort-armchair
story: The hotels, bars and restaurants are quiet, the visitors are at home. Even the Boat of Garten osprey nest seems to be missing its usual occupants.Water sports at Loch Morlich and Loch Insh are on hold, and the winding road up to Cairngorm Mountainrsquos ski area has been taken over by the resident reindeer herd.The mountains, lochs, forest trails and attractions that span the Cairngorms ndash Scotlandrsquos outdoor playground ndash should have been bustling with visitors enjoying one of the best spells of springtime weather for years.Instead, even the BBCrsquos Springwatch programme, filmed from its Cairngorms hub and which showcases the area in all its natural glory, is staying away.Now, to help us all enjoy a flavour of Highland le, Cairngorms National Park has unveiled plans to bring the nature, sounds, culture and scenery that makes it so special to our homes.For  days from Friday, May , a series of online events will offer a flavour of Britainrsquos biggest national park, including special reports highlighting conservation work to protect endangered wildcats and capercaillies, fun quizzes, music and art.The online festival replaces the Cairngorms Nature BIG Weekend, an annual springtime celebration of the national park which typically sees dozens of free activities and first-hand experiences for visitors.Instead, every day from Friday onwards, the Cairngorms BIG  Days Of Nature will showcase the parkrsquos wildle and nature online, with special emphasis on how the natural world can help support our mental health and wellbeing.Along with traditional music from local artists, the  days of virtual events will include art classes offering tips for wildle drawing and interviews with people working on the frontline of nature conservation across the park.Lucy Ford, Cairngorms National Park Authority conservation engagement officer, said: ldquoIt was such a disappointment that the BIG Weekend had to be rolled over to  after all the hard work everyone had put in.ldquoUnable to invite people here in lockdown, we decided we would take the celebration to them.ldquoI am very excited about what we have planned. All the event providers have joined in and each day has a theme.ldquoThere are ideas and activities for the whole family.The  days of online events will spotlight Cairngormsrsquo ldquoat risk wildcats and capercaillies alongside less well-known rare scabious mining bees, found in only a handful of locations and which nest in burrows in the ground, and Kentish Glory moths.Identied as a conservation priority species, the moths are only found in the northeast, in areas of young birch such as moorland or regenerating woodland.There will also be special reports on the parkrsquos bats, alpine plants and peatland restoration.ldquoWe know that being exposed to nature is proven to have a positive effect on our mental wellbeing and so we will be featuring ideas and activities to get people involved from their own homes, added Ford.The role nature plays in mental health and wellbeing and tackling climate change will also be included in the festival, with a keynote talk from Chris Stark, chief executive of the Committee on Climate Change at the Cairngorms Climate Conference, along with films that spotlight landscape scale projects designed to help tackle the climate emergency.A film from Alzheimer Scotlandrsquos Tipi project will highlight how the outdoors can aid people living with dementia and their families, while arts events include music from traditional musicians Hamish Napier and Jenny Sturgeon.Sturgeon, who was due to be open the BIG Weekend with the Highland launch of her new work inspired by Nan Shepherdrsquos book The Living Mountain, said: ldquoNature and the natural world informs and inspires my music and is a great stress reliever.ldquoI grew up near the Cairngorms and walking in the hills and catching glimpses of species there is always a delight.ldquoNow more than ever the outdoors and watching wildle has taken on a new meaning.Cairngorms BIG  Days Of Nature begins on Friday, May . The full programme is available at www.cairngormsnaturebigweekend, or visit www.facebook cairngormsnatureHow to keep tabs on your Cairngorms favouritesMissing your spring visit to Cairngorms National Park  Herersquos how to stay in touch with whatrsquos going on.Reindeer talesWith paths and roads clear of traffic, the Cairngorms reindeer herd has been taking the easy route to new pastures and saving keepers the problem of scrambling through rough heather to reach them.Britainrsquos only free-ranging reindeer herd has also been welcoming delightfully cute calves, while an adoption programme has been launched to raise vital funds lost during lockdown.Regular updates, cute photographs and details of how to adopt a reindeer are posted on the Cairngorms Reindeer Herd Facebook page.Plant leA highlight of the Big  Days of Nature will be a short film highlighting Plantle Scotlandrsquos work in Cairngorms National Park.Due to be screened online on Saturday, it was partly filmed at Anagach Woods, where there are rare wintergreen, creeping ladyrsquos tresses, twinflower and stagrsquos horn clubmoss, the spores of which were once used to create magicianrsquos flash powder.The film includes an explanation of Gaelic plant names and film of tiny arctic alpine flowers flourishing on the windswept Cairngorms plateau.To follow Plantle Scotlandrsquos work in the Cairngorms, its floral s who monitor plants and its Cairngorms Wild Plants Project, go to www.plantle.org.uk scotland or like Plantle Scotland on Facebook.Beer and banterMissing a pint at the bar of the Cairngorm Hotel in Aviemore, a foot-tapping evening in front of a roaring fire with some fiddle music in the background, or just some glorious scenery The Pine Marten Bar and Scran at Glenmore has been treating Facebook followers to daily images of dazzling sunsets, Loch Morlich scenes and news updates with plenty of banter thrown in ndash including indoor skateboarding.Wash it down with a beer ordered online from the Cairngorm Brewery or a Speyside malt.Hit the hillsCairngorms National Parkrsquos website is calling for walkers to bag a Munro by signing up for its virtual challenge.Walk  minutes every day for six days to claim Ben Macdui, an hour a day for two days to bag Beinn arsquo Ghlo and  minutes for four days to add Lochnagar to your "done it" list.If cycling is your thing, Ride Cairngorm on Facebook is packed with pictures of bikes against stunning mountain scenery and the occasional competition.Bird leKeep on top of whatrsquos happening with the parkrsquos birdle by following RSPB Loch Garten Abernethyrsquos Facebook updates.Therersquos little news of ospreys nesting, but there is a species of the day feature, regular links to blogs and podcasts, and ideas to create wildle features in gardens.Brush up on your knowledge of birdsong by visiting Cairngorms National Parkrsquos website ndash therersquos a page dedicated to the sounds of the park.On the estateLynbreck Croft on the outskirts of Aviemore, spans  acres and is home to thistle-chomping pigs, a couple of Highland cows, chickens, bees and a tea plantation.Owners Sandra Baer and Lynn Cassells post regular vlogs and Facebook updates with plenty of pictures of le on the farm.Swing by Alvie Estate on Facebook too for regular news from the Kingussie area, images of days gone by and plenty of pictures of new arrivals on the farm.Meanwhile, Balmoral Castle and Estatersquos page is updated daily with photographs and news from the royal residence.

title: whisky-tourism-can-key-scotlands-post-coronavirus-bounce-back-says-festival-chairman
story: By James CampbellWhen we wrapped our phenomenally successful Spirit of Speyside Festival  with plans in place for an even bigger and better collection of events in , we never could have imagined we would be where we are today. The festival has been cancelled and cultural gatherings across the country have been put on hold or postponed.It goes without saying that in these times our priority is the health and safety of our families, our loved ones ndash whether thatrsquos hugs with grandchildren, seeing friends or enjoying shared experiences such as the Spirit of Speyside Festival which should have been held last week. However, what I have witnessed emerging is hope, resilience and a strong Scottish can-do attitude. In the whisky industry, in particular, within days of lockdown being announced, distilleries rallied together to manufacture large quantities of vitally important hand sanitiser.Itrsquos a true testament to our Scottish fighting spirit that we will not take this lying down. We adapt and move forward as best we can. Irsquom extremely proud of the Speyside community and our wider Spirit of Speyside Festival family across the world for keeping the spirit of the festival alive.Whisky and tourism are pivotal sectors to the Scottish economy. Three out of every five tourists come to Speyside for whisky tourism. In fact, the Spirit of Speyside Festival welcomed visitors from  dferent countries to its th anniversary event last year. The Spirit of Speyside Whisky Festival has become an iconic event on the international whisky calendar, appealing to both the whisky curious and connoisseurs in a region that has become one of the fastest-growing tourist destinations in the UK.As well as being home to the highest concentration of distilleries of all whisky regions in the world, Speyside also produces the largest volume of whisky, as well as an increasingly wide range of spirits ndash we are now home to  dferent gin companies.This is why we introduced our Speyside Gin Festival in June, to create a new weekend for both locals and visitors to enjoy, then we celebrate all our great Speyside whisky companies and local gin and craft beer companies at our Distilled Festival, all under one roof in Elgin, normally at the end of August.This yearrsquos Gin Festival has sadly been cancelled and a decision is yet to be made about Distilled. However, based on current guidance, we feel itrsquos unlikely it will go ahead.But the appetite for whisky is there and it will remain. I am confident our economy will be rebuilt and we will work hard to do this together. According to VisitScotland, the Spirit of Speyside Festival welcomed visitors from  dferent countries to its th anniversary festival last year. This is a sector that is worth pound million to the regionrsquos economy. When we emerge from the other side of the pandemic Irsquom certain these figures will only increase.International travel is sure to take a downturn in the short term, while people look for local and regional travel opportunities on their doorstep. Domestic travel is set to be the first to bounce back when restrictions are eased, and I canrsquot wait to welcome tourists from all over the UK to beautul Speyside.Our Team Speyside approach to tourism will pull us through these tough times in our part of the world, of that I have no doubt. Our whisky distilleries will reopen, glasses will be raised to good health, and visitors from across the world will once again immerse themselves in Malt Whisky Country. Never will the term ldquoslaacuteinte mhaith hold more weight than it will when this is all over. Let us all toast to that this World Whisky Day on May .James Campbell, is the chairman, Spirit of Speyside Whisky FestivalRead more: First Look: Diageorsquos Edinburgh whisky tourism experience at nightRead more: Coronavirus: Tourism rallying call to help firms tackle crisis

title: exercise-coronavirus-lockdown-day-optimism
story: This is notoriously sedentary Scotland, it was a chore to leave the house just the once and now were meant to be grateful we can go out for a run and a cycle  Crikey.Were the giant queues at KFC and Starbucks when the drive thrus opened not a hint at where the nations heart truly lies  Not in brisk walks and hitting our , steps but in getting something deep fried and caffeinated.I jest, of course. The deep fried Mars bar cliche of Scots is tired and lazy.But I tell you what, theres been nothing like two months on house arrest to prompt me to remember the gym with a fondness I never felt when it was open and minutes from my flat. Mere weeks ago I would conjure up the flimsiest of excuses not to exercise."But my trainers... they take so long to lace up." And back to the couch Id go.Being told that outdoor exercise is no longer allowed, except in little doses, has been exactly what I needed to appreciate the glory of stretching my legs and working up a hard earned sweat and I cant imagine Im alone there.The First Ministers announcement that the lockdown rules will be slightly eased has led to daydreams about when and where and how I might wander twice per day.But lockdown has led to another interesting development. The discovery of online classes.To my absolute delight, Scottish Ballet announced it would move its specialist classes online. At .am every day a Facebook live class is held for a iety of dferent audiences: Dance for Parkinsonrsquos, Time to Dance for people living with dementia, and Elevate for people living with Multiple Sclerosis.A Thursday is Regenerate, for the over-s. Wonderfully, Ma Stewart has taken to the Regenerate class with gusto, though shed port de bras me in the face for telling you, and is having a wonderful time learning a new skill despite being isolated at home.I took ballet classes for more than  years and miss them dreadfully so was thrilled to learn that, on a Friday morning, one of my favourite Scottish Ballet dancers, Bethany Kingsley-Garner, was taking a class "for all ages".I made an excuse not to be showing up for the morning work Teams video conference and got my leggings on, dug out my old ballet shoes and was there, feet in first position, ready to go.It turned out that "all ages" more meant "for parents and children" but you know, I had a wonderful time pretending to be a swan and opening up to the sunshine like a spring flower.Its amazing what the body remembers, even after a long time sedentary. Despite it being a class for tots, I could feel my muscles readily moving back into the old, familiar patterns, my big toe drawing the swirl of a ron de jambe on the floor or arms lting into fth position.Its sad to discover my grand battement are more of an extremely pathetic battement but it seems my right hip is giving me gyp. Perhaps all the sitting, who knows.But a hobbling right hip led to the next new indoor exercise discovery. The near-cult like movement of Yoga By Adrienne. Yoga is another love that has fallen by the wayside as work and le took over.I was looking for some hip opener exercises to help ease the pain, seeking out a little something for my neck, stf from hunching over a laptop at my dining table.There she was - Adrienne Mishler. Apparently shes already an international yoga star with millions of devoted YouTube followers. Who knew  Well, as I say millions of people. And no wonder.Shes perfect in a pandemic. No overly dficult, Instagram focused headstands here. "Try thisyou can," she tells me in a first video, "Maybe youll manage it, maybe you never will."Thats the spirit.My yoga mat has become five feet of safe space, with the soothing sound of Adrienne guiding me into a downward dog.I was becoming accustomed to being physically unambitious but now these online tutorials have sparked me back into action.Im almost sad about being allowed back outdoors, away from the safety of the gentle online guidance of Bethany and Adrienne.Its perhaps ironic that one tiny positive is the rediscovery of long lost movement in a lockdown.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: public-transport-users-told-face-away-one-another-unable-observe-social-distancing
story: The guidance acknowledges that "there may be situations where you cant keep a suitable distance from people" such as on busier services or at peak times.It says: "In these cases, you should avoid physical contact, try to face away from other people."The official advice goes on: "The risk of infection increases the closer you are to another person with the virus and the amount of time you spend in close contact."The Government move comes as yet again there have been pictures posted on social media of people on crowded London Underground trains.Matt Hancock, the UK Government Health Secretary, was challenged about the safety of people being crammed "like sardines" on the Tube this morning.He told ITVrsquos This Morning: "Less than one in six people commute on public transport of course, that figure is much bigger in London. People should avoid public transport unless they absolutely have to use it because it is safer when there is fewer people on it."He suggested more people should get on a bike to go to work."You say not everybody can cycle, thats true, but lots more people can than do and now is actually a good time to start cycling to work because there is hardly any traffic on the roads so its much more pleasant to cycle than in normal times," Mr Hancock said.A key worker has said that social distancing was "impossible to maintain" on his journey to work on the London Underground this morning.Terry McCarthy, , a supermarket store manager, took a photo at Canada Water at am and shared it to Twitter with the caption: "And they try to tell us the tube is at % capacity! This is dangerous and putting lives at risk!"He explained how his place of work was too far away to walk or cycle to."Both the  and the train were busier than what it has been the last few weeks. There were too many people in the carriage and social distancing was impossible to maintain," added Mr McCarthy.Transport operators in England are being urged to rearrange, remove or limit seating "to try and ensure social distancing is observed".This could include blocking off seats in close proximity to others and removing face-to-face seating.Single users of black cabs and minicabs are being advised to sit in the back left-hand seat of taxis.All transport operators have been issued guidance on ensuring stations and services are regularly cleaned.Grant Shapps, the Transport Secretary, who will make a Commons statement on the guidance this afternoon, said: "Transport operators and staff have been working hard to ensure that people who need to get to work are able to do so, including crucial NHS workers and all those on the front line of the fight against the virus."Alongside the cycling and walking revolution we are launching and clear guidance to passengers and operators published today, we can all play our part by following the advice and reducing pressure on public transport."If we take these steps, all those who need to use public transport should feel confident that they can do so safely with the space to maintain social distancing as far as possible," he added.Passengers south of the border are being advised to "avoid using public transport where possible" and should "instead try to walk, cycle or drive".People who do travel should be "thinking carefully about the times, routes and ways you travel".The guidance recommends:*keeping two metres apart from others wherever possible*wearing a face coveringyou can*using contactless payment where possible*avoiding rush hour travel where feasible*washing or sanitising your hands as soon as possible before and after travel and*following advice from staff and being considerate to others.The new advice follows the announcement of a pound billion package of cycling and walking investment for England that will deliver a ldquogreen revolution in travel, aiming to ease the pressure on public transport services by helping more people than ever choose alternative forms of travel.This includes pound million for local authorities in England to create pop-up bike lanes with protected space for cycling, wider pavements, safer junctions, and cycle and bus-only corridors.The overall expenditure will produce a knock-on windfall for the Scottish Government of around poundm via the Barnett Formula.

title: chancellor-rishi-sunak-extends-uk-govt-furlough-scheme-end-october-flexibility-part-time-work
story: Responding to an Urgent Question asked by Labour in the House of Commons, the Chancellor explained that the Job Retention Scheme would run for another four months.Until the end of July, there would be no changes but from the start of August until the end of October the scheme would change to facilitate a sharing of the burden with employers of paying % of peoplersquos salaries, up to pound, a month.New statistics published today revealed the furlough scheme ndash described by Mr Sunak as a ldquoworld-leading economic intervention - had protected . million jobs and supported almost one million businesses.The Institute for Fiscal Studies calculated that extending the scheme in its current form for five months to the end of July would add an extra pound billion, bringing the total by then to around poundbn. The further three-month extension would push the overall cost higher.He said all sectors and regions of the UK would continue to be covered with greater flexibility to support the transition back to work.The Chancellor told MPs: "Employers currently using the scheme will be able to bring furloughed employees back part-time. And we will ask employers to start sharing with the Government the cost of paying peoples salaries. Full details will follow by the end of May."But Mr Sunak, who turned  today, went on: ldquoI want to assure people today of one thing that wont change. Workers will through the combined efforts of Government and employers continue to receive the same level of overall support as they do now at % of their current salary up to pound, a month."Im extending the scheme because I wont give up on the people who rely on it. Our message today is simple: we stood behind Britains workers and businesses as we came into this crisis and we will stand behind them as we come through the other side."Later, when askedthe scheme could be extended beyond October, the Chancellor told the House that everything would be kept under review, noting: ldquoBut my expectation is by then the scheme should end. As I have said before we have stretched and strained to be as generous as possible to businesses and workers, which is why we have made the decision we have made today, which is important to me personally.ldquoBut, of course, as I have also said, this scheme is expensive. It is the right thing to do the cost of not acting would have been far higher.ldquoBut it is not something that can continue indefinitely into the future. Eight months of total support is a considerable amount of time and, now we have a plan from the Prime Minister with a path to reopening those parts of our economy that are closed, I believe we can get the country back on track, get people back into work and this scheme will help them to do it in a measured way, a phased way, and protect as many jobs as possible.Nicola Sturgeon gave the announcement a cautious welcome.Speaking at the Scottish Governmentrsquos daily briefing on Covid-, the First Minister said: ldquoAn extension to October is welcome. Hopefully, with the caveat that Irsquove not seen the detail yet, on the face of it that should avoid clf edges, where companies have to start redundancy processes because theyrsquore worried about the furlough scheme coming to an end within the timescale that they have to consult around redundancies.ldquoSo, it gives companies more time to do that and, hopefully, over that period we are going to see the further suppression of the virus and that, albeit gradual and perhaps relatively slow restart of the economy.She added: ldquoFrom what I have been able to gather so far, the Chancellorrsquos announcement is welcome but I will wait and see the detail before commenting any further on it.Jackson Carlaw, leader of the Scottish Conservatives said: ldquoWe all know that the Covid- pandemic represents a colossal economic threat as well as a public health crisis.ldquoThe Chancellor has today given millions of workers across Scotland economic security right through until October.ldquoIntroducing part-time flexibility into the scheme in July is something that businesses have been asking for and is very welcome.Mr Carlaw said the simplicity and clarity of the Chancellorrsquos message was striking.ldquoThis crisis is not over, there is still a long road ahead, but Scottish employees and employers have been given an enormous safety net, he added.In the Commons, Anneliese Dodds for Labour said many were taken aback by comments attributed to Government officials suggesting people need to be "weaned off an addiction" to the furlough scheme.The Shadow Chancellor said she had only heard about the Governmentrsquos changes "in the last few seconds" and will examine them "very, very carefully".Ms Dodds said people do not want to be furloughed, adding in the Commons: "Its critically important they are not penalised for that choice. We welcome the flexibility mentioned, weve asked for this repeatedly."Mr Sunak replied: "The use of the word addiction is not one I have ever used and not one I agree with."Nobody who is on the furlough scheme wants to be on this scheme. People up and down this country believe in the dignity of their work, going to work, providing for their families, its not their fault their business has been asked to close or asked to stay at home."That is why I established this scheme to support these people and their livelihoods at this critical time."Alison Thewliss for the SNP asked the Chancellorhe recognised that removing or reducing wage support levels in the furlough scheme prematurely would increase Universal Credit claims and ldquoforce workers back to work before its safe for them and risk a second peak "Mr Sunak replied: "Just to clary, there will be no reduction in the level of support for those on the scheme. Its crystal clear those on the scheme have that reassurance the level of support that they receive will not be changed."Tory backbencher Mel Stride, who chairs the Commons Treasury Committee, said: ldquoThe extension of the furlough scheme, allowing furloughed employees to work part time, and with employers asked to contribute are all welcome steps from the Chancellor."However, he said the devil would be in the detail and the committee would carefully scrutinise the changes.ldquoThe Chancellor also said that there will be no changes to the scheme until July. This will be worrying for those who continue to fall through the gaps of the Governmentrsquos support measures such as the lack of furlough support to help cover idend income generated through self-employment."Outwith Westminster, Liz Cameron, Chief Executive of the Scottish Chambers of Commerce hailed the furlough scheme extension as ldquogreat news.She said: ldquoBusinesses and employees across Scotland will be extremely relieved by the Chancellorrsquos decision to extend the furlough scheme to October rather than face a clf edge with its originally planned withdrawal at the end of June.ldquoThis direct employee financial support has been a leline which has enabled many jobs to be retained rather than businesses having to face making massive redundancies. As we begin to consider a lsquo to workplacersquo plan to restart the economy, flexibility in these schemes will be paramount to protecting jobs until businesses are able to trade normally once more.Ms Cameron said the SCC looked forward to seeing further detail on the proposed employersrsquo contribution.ldquoWe would ask that this takes into consideration, particularly for SMEs, their ability to pay contributions depending on how quickly their income recovers as lock down eases. Trading conditions will dfer depending on location and sector and the flexibility of the furlough scheme must take these factors on board.ldquoWe will continue our engagement with the Treasury to make sure business support remains flexible and accessible for Scottish businesses, she added.Andrew McRae, the Federation of Small Business Scotlandrsquos Policy Chairman, said: ldquoTodayrsquos shrewd decisions from the Chancellor will give thousands of large and small Scottish employers the right sort of flexibility. The move to allow operators to partially furlough their staff while they consider how to get back up to speed should mean more businesses have the right tools at their disposal.ldquoIn the coming weeks, smaller firms will want to understand the next steps for the scheme. Policymakers will need to carefully consider how to co-ordinate financial support for businesses with advice to firms about how and when to reopen safely, he added.Dame Carolyn Fairbairn, the CBI Director-General, said firms would want more detail and asked for ministers to be willing to be flexiblethere were a second peak.ldquoExtending the furlough to avoid a June clf-edge continues the signicant efforts made already and will protect millions of jobs."Introducing much-needed flexibility is extremely welcome. It will prepare the ground for firms that are reawakening, while helping those who remain in hibernation. Thats essential as the UK economy revives step-by-step, while supporting livelihoods."Edwin Morgan for the Institute of Directors said plans for part-time s by the Government were welcome."A part-time furlough provides a much-needed launch ramp so businesses can start to get back up to speed. A more flexible approach will allow firms to raise activity levels in tandem with demand, helping to avoid cashflow challenges."We now need further clarity around employers contributions. Many firms that would normally be on strong footing are still in dire straits. The extension puts yet more onus on helping those who have been left out in the cold. Countless small company directors have found scant support, and Government shouldnt turn a blind eye to them," he added.

title: sturgeon-tells-english-firms-treat-scottish-staff-differently
story: The First Minister said thatfirms had staff living in Scotland, they should follow the Scottish Governments lockdown guidance ldquowherever your head office is, wherever yoursquore based, not necessarily expect them toto work in the same manneras staff living in England.She said that included staff living in Scotland whose normal workplace was just over the border in England.The Scottish lockdown istighter than the UK Government version, which was changed this week for Englandwith the ldquostay at home message replaced by ldquostay alertThe UK version says people in England should work at home where possible, but says ldquofood production, construction, manufacturing, logistics, distribution and scientic research in laboratories should be open.The Scottish guidance is for construction to be closed.The UK guidance says it should be "considered alongside local public health and safety requirements for Scotland", but does not say which guidancetakes precedence.However at the Scottish Governmentrsquos daily briefing on Covid-, Ms Sturgeon was clear thatthe Scottish advice must apply to workers living in Scotland, eventhey normally commuted to work in England.She began by urging employers in Scotland not to reopen prematurely or put pressure on employees toto work too soon.She said: ldquoI know that the UK Government published guidance for businesses yesterday.ldquoI want to stress that this guidance is not yet operational in Scotland at this stage, since we are not currently encouraging more people to go back to work.ldquoI would ask instead that all employers follow the Scottish Government guidance.ldquoI am very grateful for the fact that the vast majority of employers have been so responsible throughout this crisis ndash so I am sure that most will do this, and will not urge workers to come back to work prematurely.ldquoAnd for employees, I would remind you thatyou think your working conditions are unsafe, you have rights under employment legislation.ldquoIf you have a trade union in your workplace, and you have concerns about your working conditions, you should also be able to talk to them.ldquoThe Scottish Government is working with employers and trade unions to develop guidance on safe workplaces which has the confidence of businesses and workers.Askedher message was the same to employers south of the border, for example in and around Carlisle, who had workers currently living in Scotland,Ms Sturgeon replied: ldquoYes, unequivocally."She went on: "My message applied to all employers, clearly employing people who work in Scotland, I would hope all employers across the UK would be responsible, but my responsibility of course is for those who live in Scotland.ldquoSo I would say to employers, wherever your head office is, wherever yoursquore based,you are employing people who live in Scotland, have regard to the Scottish Government guidance. Indeed, that is what the UK Government would tell you to do as well.ldquoWe are going through a process that will allow us, at the right time and in the right phasing, to give people the confidence that they can go back to work safely.Asked about reports that Burger King, McDonaldrsquos and Starbucks were planning to reopen some outlets in Scotland despite the lockdown, Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoRight now, because our progress against this virus is fragile, we must be cautious.ldquoWe must not prematurely lt these restrictions and risk the virus running out of control.ldquoI make no apology for being cautious about this and I would say to employers of all shapes and sizes, and all sectors, You should be following in Scotland, Scottish Government advice.ldquoWe are not yet encouraging any businesses that are not open right now, or any workers who are not working right now, to be back in operation.ldquoOf course that will change in the weeks ahead and we want to get back to as close to normal operation for businesses as quickly as possible, but that has to be done safely, and it has to be done in the right order, so we can give workers confidence they are safe as they can be.

title: return-real-kashmir-fc-bbc-scotland-review
story: BBC Scotland, pmFERGUSON, Guardiola, Klopp, Benitez: pretty decent football managers you would agree. But which of them ever had to battle his way through packs of rabid wild dogs to research the opposition As this follow up to last yearrsquos Scottish Bafta-winning documentary showed, Davie Robertson, the Scots coachof Real Kashmir FC, continued to live in interesting times. Sometimes a touch too interesting. ldquoEverything that can go wrong goes wrong here, said Robertson by way of an introduction to the region. It was hard to disagree.On his arrival in India the government abolished Kashmirrsquos parliament and assumed direct control. It was like England taking Scotlandrsquos parliament away, explained the former Rangers, Aberdeen, and Leeds United player.Greg Clarkrsquos film began with Robertson at home in Aberdeen, preparing to say cheerio to his we, Kym, once more. He had mixed emotions about going, knowing how much he would miss home.But he also missed being a part of the game he clearly loved. ldquoI knowI didnrsquot have a job I wouldnrsquot be a happy person.Kym was told not to wave him off at the airport because it was ldquojust too sad". So off he went.A short time later we saw this gentle, sensitive soul having his team talk interrupted by two men making a delivery to the dressing room.ldquoWhat the **** is this  roared Robertson. ldquoCould this not be done before we ******* arrive  **** me. Put the ******* thing down and **** off.Yes, he had lost none of his world-class cussing skills. If all the expletives were deleted from his speech the only things left would be some pronouns and a couple of lonely verbs.Having several sides to his character is what makes Robertson such a great subject for a documentary. He is part ruffian, part romantic a hard man who is not afraid to hug a player going through a dficult time a wee working class guy from Aberdeen who spends his time off exploring the mountains and visiting a Buddhist monastery . Not your average football manager, then.He was funny, too, as when he told Kym about his day in the mountains where the altitude made him feel dreadful. ldquoThe worst day of my le, he said, ldquoand Irsquove played at Albion Rovers.Real Kashmir FC was one of the new BBC Scotland channelrsquos biggest hits, and the sequel uses the same winning blend of matches and travelogue, with the story revolving around Robertson.The drama can be over-played at times ndash everything seems to be a crunch this or a high-stakes that ndash and the film could have done with more background on how Robertson came to be there in the first place. A few in-depth conversations with club owner Sandeep Chatoo would not have gone amiss either.Robertson is not the first Scot to find himself a stranger in a foreign land, as he saw for himself on a visit to the Scottish cemetery in Kolkata. He asked his guide how the local people got on with the Scots in colonial times.ldquoThe Scottish ruled us, tortured us, said the guide.ldquoTortured  said Robertson.ldquoVery much so.ldquoPhysical torture ldquoPhysical torture.Every day is a school day, even for coaches.There was not a lot of on the pitch action, largely because le was far more interesting off it, as when Robertson went to a dodgy part of town to use the internet during lockdown. That was where he met the marauding hounds. ldquoTherersquos *******  dogs waiting there, licking their lips, he said, finally opting to go another way.Occasionally, and despite having one of his sons playing in the team, being away from home got to him. Christmas Day was particularly hard.But then as we learned from the postscript to this engaging film, Robertson and his team, like millions of others around the globe, were about to have their lives upended by what commentators might call a dramatic last minute own goal, this one from the left foot of Mother Nature.Not even the mighty, and mighty likeable Robertson, could hustle his way out of that one.Available on iPlayer
