title: strategy announced lead wales lockdown
story: The framework will help to determine when the strict stay-at-home restrictions can begin to be relaxed in Wales and will help to find a way for people in Wales to live and work alongside coronavirus.A Wales-wide programme of surveillance, case identication, and contract tracing is being developed through the office of the Chief Medical Officer, Dr Frank Atherton. This will highlight the importance of community testing and support the containment of emerging coronavirus infections as and when restrictions are eased.Launching the framework, the First Minister said: ldquoOur approach to date has been one of lockdown. We have taken unprecedented steps to protect everyone, but particularly those most at risk from serious illness.ldquoThis has helped the NHS prepare and cope with coronavirus and, even though we have sadly seen more than  people die, it has helped to save many more lives. But this strategy comes with its own costs to peoplersquos wider health and wellbeing and long-term costs to our economy.ldquoWe are keeping these regulations under constant review. We know coronavirus will be with us for a long time yet but we want to see whether there are things we can do while we continue to tackle the virus and while the search for better treatments and a vaccine continue.The framework ndash and the seven questions ndash will help determine when the time is right to relax some of the stay-at home regulations.The seven questions are:bull Would easing a restriction have a negative effect on containing the virus bull Does a particular measure pose a low risk of further infection bull How can it be monitored and enforced bull Can it be reversed quicklyit creates unintended consequences bull Does it have a positive economic benefit bull Does it have a positive impact on peoplersquos wellbeing bull Does it have a positive impact on equality The Chief Medical Officer for Walesrsquo office has developed the Wales-wide programme of surveillance, case identication, and contract tracing.It will have four main strands ndash improved surveillance of cases of coronavirus effective identication of cases and contact tracing learning from international experience and engaging with the public.Dr Atherton said: ldquoAction to ease the lockdown restrictions will need to be supported by a comprehensive public health response, which will need to developed quickly and at scale.ldquoAcross the UK, we have worked and put in place unprecedented measures to contain and delay the spread of coronavirus. We have also worked to reduce the overall impact of the virus by strengthening essential services, including healthcare.ldquoWe are now working towards a new recovery phase to lead us out of the pandemic but only when the conditions are right.The First Minister added: ldquoCoronavirus is not going to disappear ndash it is likely it will be with us for a long time. We will need to have some sort of restrictions in place for some time yet to continue to control the spread of the virus and reduce community transmission. This framework will help us determine what is right for Wales.ldquoThere is a long road ahead of us towards recovery to pre-pandemic levels, butwe continue to work together, I hope we will be able to make changes to the restrictions and see a gradualto something resembling normal le.The Welsh Government has worked closely with the rest of the UK throughout the pandemic and has shared the development of the framework with the Scottish, Northern Irish and the UK governments. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... produce , face visors for essential workers.Ysgol Y Deri, on Sully Road, has designed and made over  plastic face visors for health workers and care home staff in the Vale.Now the school has ordered services to get our care homes what they need, said Mr Britton.ldquoTheyrsquovebeen really well received.According to Mr Britton, the material for the visors was purchased using funds from the school earlier this week following a review by the Penarth Town Council.The council previously closed the cemetery to visitors in March to tackle the spread of the coronavirus.The cemetery will be be open for visits on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays between am and pm, a council spokesman confirmed.He said: ldquoWe understand peoplersquos wish in the current pandemic to mourn and pay respects to those who remain dear to them.ldquoTo ensure that this can continue, we ask all visitors to take good care of themselves and others by observing current health guidance, including social distancing.ldquoWe must also ask that the grounds are not used for exercise or dog walking.ldquoPlease help us look after the cemetery by taking any waste materials home.ldquoPlease note that the toilets remain closed.ldquoFor health and safety reasons, it will be necessary for us to close the grounds during a funeral.ldquoIn current circumstances grounds maintenance has been scaled back and normal maintenance levels will resume when it is safe to do so.ldquoWe hope that reopening the cemetery brings comfort and thank you for supporting us in keeping yourself and others safe.The change comes after the Welsh Government introduced minor adjustments to the lockdown measures.The new rules allow people to exercise more than once a day near their home and enabled local authorities to begin the process of planning how to safely reopen libraries and municipal recycling centres.Garden centres are also allowed to reopen.Last week there were several incidents at the Merthyr Dyfan Cemetery in Barry which reopened on May .Barry Town Council received reports that visitors had not observed social distancing.On one occasion, a member of the public spat at a security guard whilst another title: archaeologists working home make new discoveries
story: Digging may be on hold due to the pandemic, but the team have found parts of two Roman roads, around  prehistoric or Roman large embanked settlement enclosures, and some  prehistoric burial mounds, as well as the remains of hundreds of medieval farms, field systems and quarries.Those leading the project believe they will make many more discoveries in the coming weeks. vw,vw,px, px"A probable Iron Age or Roman enclosed settlement, defined by a band or ditch , which has been revealed by volunteers using Lidar data during lockdown The team are analysing images derived from Lidardata.This laser technology is used during aerial surveys to produce highly detailed topographical maps.Modern vegetation and buildings can be removed, allowing archaeologists to look at the shape of the land surface to find the remains of archaeological earthworks.The data is being systematically examined and cross-referenced with records of known archaeology and historic maps, meaning the total of new discoveries regularly changes.Project leader Dr Chris Smart, from the University of Exeter, said: ldquoThe South West arguably has the most comprehensive Lidar data yet available in the UK and we are using this to map as much of the historic environment as possible.ldquoThe projectrsquos current focus is the Tamar Valley, but this has been extended to include a broad swathe of land between Bodmin Moor and Dartmoor, Plymouth and Barnstaple ndash about , square kilometres in all.ldquoThis is the first major systematic analysis of Lidar data from the Tamar Valley westwards and builds upon training workshops we ran earlier in the year.ldquoOrdinarily we would now be out in the field surveying archaeological sites with groups of volunteers, or preparing for our community excavations, but this is all now on hold. vw,vw,px, px"A section of probably Roman road revealed by volunteers using light detection and rangingdata ldquoI knew there would be enthusiasm within our volunteer group to continue working during lockdown ndash one even suggested temporarily rebranding our project lsquoLockdown Landscapesrsquo ndash but I donrsquot think they realised how many new discoveries they would make.ldquoI am very grateful to our team for their efforts and am glad that we could continue to do volunteer-led research in these unsettling times. At the current rate we expect them to recognise hundreds of new archaeological sites in the coming month or two.When the worst of the pandemic is over the team intend to undertake geophysical surveys at several of the new sites as part of the project.Dr Smart added: ldquoItrsquos hard for us not to be able to carry out the work we had planned this summer ndash including an excavation at Calstock Roman fort ndash but hopefully this is only a temporary blip and we will be back out in the countryside with volunteers as soon as it is safe to do so..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Archaeologists working from home make new discoveries article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: glance new rules easing restrictions
story: Exercise is no longer limited to once a day, and those who want to go fishing are able to do so.Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland are either adhering to existing rules or writing their own amendments.Here, the PA news agency looks at what people are able to do and what is still off-limits:ndash Exercise and sportPeople in England will now be able to exercise more than once a day and with one person who is not from their household, so long as social distancing requirements are still met.Golf courses, outdoor tennis and basketball courts can be used, and people can also swim in lakes and the sea. vw,vw,px, px"Golf courses in England will be allowed to reopen However, gathering with more than one member of another household is still forbidden, along with swimming in a public pool, using a playground or outdoor gym, and exercising in indoor leisure centres or facilities.ndash TravelDriving to outdoor open spaces, either alone or with members of your household is allowed, as well as travelling to beaches or beauty spots in England. Similarly, travelling to the countryside is also permitted.Regulations against going on holiday or staying overnight at a holiday home or second home still apply.ndash RecreationGoing for a picnic, sunbathing and relaxing in a public place is now allowed in England, while people can also fishing on their own, or with one other person while adhering to social distancing rules.We need to stay alert to stop the spread of the virus.#StayAlert pic CsqtctnTSNmdash UK Prime MinisterMay , People are not allowed to visit the homes of friends and family ndash unless it is for care and medical reasons, or to take a child to another household with whom parental responsibilities are shared.Visiting a private or ticketed attraction is also not permitted..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: At a glance: New rules on easing restrictions article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice.
